questions.question:
Jonathon and his dad were both born on $5 ^ \text{th}$ August.

Jonathon was born in $1985$ and his father is $32$ years older than him.

In which year was his dad born?
Fill in the gaps

solutionDetails.working:
Let the missing  number $= a$

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
60 - a  &= 43 \\\\
a       &= 60 - 43 \\\\
a       &= 17
\end{aligned}
$

children.question: $\ldots \times 40 = 280$

solutionDetails.working:
Let the missing  number $= a$

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
a \times 40 &= 280 \\\\
a           &= \dfrac{280}{40} \\\\
a           &= \dfrac{7 \times 40}{40} \\\\
a           &= \dfrac{7 \times \cancel{40}}{\cancel{40}} \\\\
a           &= 7
\end{aligned}
$
solutionDetails.keepInMind: - Use the correct order of operations (BIDMAS).

children.question: $\ldots \div 30 = 5$

solutionDetails.working:
Let the missing  number $= a$

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
a \div 30       &= 5 \\\\
\dfrac{a}{30}   &= 5\\\\
a               &= 5 \times 30 \\\\
a               &= 150
\end{aligned}
$

$

a      &= 7
\end{aligned}
$

children.question: $200 \times \ldots = 160$

solutionDetails.working:
Let the missing number = $a$

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
200 \times a     &= 160 \\\\
a                 &= \dfrac {160} {200} \\\\
a                 &= \dfrac {40 \times 4} {40 \times 5} \\\\
a                 &= \dfrac { \cancel{40} \times 4} { \cancel{40} \times 5} \\\\
a                 &= \dfrac {4} {5}
\end{aligned}
$
solutionDetails.keepInMind:
- When dividing by a fraction, multiply by the reciprocal.
- Write the final answer with the correct unit.

</svg>

Calculate the missing angle in this isosceles triangle.


<svg width="260" height="160" viewBox="0 0 260 160" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" role="img" aria-label="Bar chart">
  <line x1="30" y1="130" x2="240" y2="130" stroke="black" stroke-width="2"/>
  <line x1="30" y1="130" x2="30" y2="20" stroke="black" stroke-width="2"/>
  <rect x="55" y="70" width="25" height="60" fill="none" stroke="black" stroke-width="2"/>
  <rect x="100" y="50" width="25" height="80" fill="none" stroke="black" stroke-width="2"/>
  <rect x="145" y="90" width="25" height="40" fill="none" stroke="black" stroke-width="2"/>
  <rect x="190" y="35" width="25" height="95" fill="none" stroke="black" stroke-width="2"/>
</svg>

solutionDetails.working:
Let the missing angle $= a$

As the triangle is an isosceles triangle, the third angle $= a$

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
a  + a + 96                             &= 180   \\\\
2a + 96                                 &= 180  \\\\
2a                                      &= 180 - 96  \\\\
2a                                      &= 84  \\\\
a                                       &= \dfrac {84} {2}  \\\\
a                                       &= \dfrac {42 \times 2} {2}  \\\\
a                                       &= \dfrac {42 \times \cancel{2}}{\cancel{2}}   \\\\
a                                       &= 42  \degree
\end{aligned}
$

Missing angle $= 42  \degree$
solutionDetails.keepInMind:
- Show each step clearly; don’t do too much in one line.
- Check units and convert if needed.

  <polygon points="40,130 220,130 140,30" fill="none" stroke="black" stroke-width="2"/>
  <text x="125" y="150" font-size="14">base</text>
  <text x="145" y="25" font-size="14">A</text>
  <text x="28" y="135" font-size="14">B</text>
  <text x="225" y="135" font-size="14">C</text>
</svg>


Show workings.

solutionDetails.working:
Let's calculate the sale price of bicycle from each deal.

**Deal A**

If the price is reduced by $25 \%$, then the sale price will be $100 - 25 = 75 \%$ of the original price. Using that, we get

$
\begin{aligned}
\text{Sale price from Deal A}     &= 75 \% \ \text{of} \ 260 \\\\
                                  &= \dfrac {75} {100} \times 260   \\\\
                                  &= \dfrac {75 \times 260 } {100}  \\\\
                                  &= \dfrac {25 \times 3 \times 4 \times 65 } {25 \times 4}  \\\\
                                  &= \dfrac {\cancel{25} \times 3 \times \cancel{4} \times 65 } {\cancel{25}  \times \cancel{4}}   \\\\
                                  &= 3 \times 65 \\\\
                                  &= \pounds 195
\end{aligned}
$

**Deal B**

$
\begin{aligned}
\text{Sale price from Deal B}     &= \pounds 205
\end{aligned}
$

Better deal $= \text{Deal A} = \pounds 195$
solutionDetails.keepInMind: - Show each step clearly; don’t do too much in one line.

How many more km did Baldwin run compared to Jeff?

solutionDetails.working:
$
\begin{aligned}
\text{Baldwin ran}     &= 7 \times 2 + 1 \times 1 \\\\
                       &= 15 \ \text{km} \\\\
 \text{Jeff ran}       &= 3 \times 2 \\\\
                       &= 6 \ \text{km} \\\\
\text{Difference}      &= 15 - 6 \\\\
                       &= 9 \ \text{km}
\end{aligned}
$

Baldwin ran $9 \ \text{km}$ more than Jeff.

questions.question:
There are $14$ boys in year $4$.

Given that $\dfrac{2}{5}$ of the year are boys, how many are girls?

solutionDetails.working:
Let the total number of students in year $4 = a$

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
\dfrac{2}{5} \times a                          &= 14  \\\\
\dfrac{2 \times a}{5}                          &= 14  \\\\
a                                              &= \dfrac{14 \times 5}{2} \\\\
                                               &= \dfrac{7 \times 2 \times 5}{2} \\\\
                                               &= \dfrac{7 \times \cancel{2} \times 5}{\cancel{2}} \\\\
                                               &= 7 \times 5 \\\\
                                               &= 35
\end{aligned}
$

$
\begin{aligned}
\text{Total children}   &= 35 \\\\
\text{Total girls}      &= \text{Total children} - \text{Total boys} \\\\
                        &= 35 - 14  \\\\
                        &= 21
\end{aligned}
$

children.question:
I am thinking of a number.

If I add $5$ to it and then divide by $2$, I get $6$.

What number am I thinking of?

solutionDetails.working:
Let the number $= a$

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
\dfrac {a + 5} { 2}    &= 6 \\\\
a + 5                  &= 6 \times 2 \\\\
a + 5                  &= 12 \\\\
a                      &= 12 - 5 \\\\
a                      &= 7
\end{aligned}
$

The number I am thinking of $= 7$

questions.question:
The number of students absent from Year $7$ was recorded as follows.

| Monday | Tuesday | Wednesday | Thursday | Friday |
|:------:|:-------:|:---------:|:--------:|:------:|
| $4$    | $6$     | $5$       | $3$      | $?$    |

If the **mean number** of students absent that week from Year $7$ was $4$, how many students were absent on Friday?

solutionDetails.working:
Let the number of students absent on Friday $= a$

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
\dfrac {4 + 6 + 5 + 3 + a} {5}          &= 4 \\\\
\dfrac {18 + a} {5}                     &= 4 \\\\
18 + a                                  &= 4 \times 5 \\\\
18 + a                                  &= 20 \\\\
a                                       &= 20 - 18 \\\\
a                                       &= 2
\end{aligned}
$

Number of students absent on Friday $= 2$

questions.question:
Gino is thinking of a number.

If he

- halves it,
- then adds $5$ to it
- and then squares it and gets $121$.

Circle the number that Gino was thinking of.

$12 \quad 17 \quad 32$

solutionDetails.working:
Let the number Gino thought of $= a$

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
\bigg(\dfrac{a}{2} + 5 \bigg)^2     &= 121 \\\\
\dfrac{a}{2} + 5                    &= \sqrt{121} \\\\
\dfrac{a}{2} + 5                    &= 11 \\\\
\dfrac{a}{2}                        &= 11 - 5 \\\\
a                                   &= 2 \times (11 - 5) \\\\
a                                   &= 2 \times 6 \\\\
a                                   &= 12
\end{aligned}
$

The number that Gino thought of $= 12$.
solutionDetails.keepInMind:
- Line up digits carefully when adding or subtracting.
- Write the final answer with the correct unit.

children.question:
The entry prices at a theme park are

|                  | Price                 |
|:-----------:     |:---------------------:|
|   Adults         |   $\pounds 6.25$ each |
|   Children       |   $\pounds 2.50$ each |

Find the cost for $2$ adults and $4$ children to visit the theme park.

The entry prices for a group are

|                  | Price                 |
|:-----------:     |:---------------------:|
|   Adults         |   $\pounds 5.00$ each |
|   Children       |   $\pounds 3.00$ each |

A group of adults and children goes to the theme park for a cost of $\pounds 44$.

There are $4$ adults in the group.
How many children are in the group?

solutionDetails.working:
Let the number of children $= c$

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
4 \times 5 + c \times 3       &= 44 \\\\
20 + 3c                       &= 44 \\\\
3c                            &= 44 - 20 \\\\
3c                            &= 24 \\\\
c                             &= \dfrac {24} {3} \\\\
c                             &= \dfrac {3 \times 8} {3} \\\\
c                             &= \dfrac {\cancel 3 \times 8} {\cancel 3} \\\\
c                             &= 8
\end{aligned}
$

Number of children $= 8$

Work out the weight of one small can.

solutionDetails.working:
Let the weight of a small can (in $\text{grams}$) $= w$


$
\begin{aligned}
\text{Total weight} &= 1.25 \ \text{kg}\\\\
                    &= 1.25 \times 1000 \ \text{grams} \\\\
                    &= 1250 \ \text{grams}
\end{aligned}
$

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
425 + 3w              &= 1250  \\\\
3w                    &= 1250 - 425  \\\\
3w                    &= 825  \\\\
w                     &= \dfrac{825}{3}  \\\\
w                     &= \dfrac{275 \times 3} {3}  \\\\
w                     &= \dfrac{275 \times \cancel 3} {\cancel 3}  \\\\
w                     &= 275 \ \text{grams}
\end{aligned}
$

Weight of a small can $= 275 \ \text{grams}$

questions.question:
There are $24$ pupils in $7\text{S}$.

Two thirds of them are boys.

Half of the boys have brown hair.

How many of pupils in $7\text{S}$ are boys with brown hair?

solutionDetails.working:
Let the number of boys $= a$

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
\text{Number of boys}      &= \dfrac {2} {3} \times 24 \\\\
a                          &= \dfrac {2 \times 24} {3} \\\\
a                          &= \dfrac {2 \times 8 \times 3} {3} \\\\
a                          &= \dfrac {2 \times 8 \times \cancel 3} {\cancel 3} \\\\
a                          &= 2 \times 8 \\\\
a                          &= 16
\end{aligned}
$

$
\begin{aligned}
\text{Boys with brown hair}       &= \dfrac {1} {2} \times a\\\\
                                  &= \dfrac {1} {2} \times 16 \\\\
                                  &= 8
\end{aligned}
$

questions.question:
The table shows Ann's marks in two tests.

|       Test    | Marks             |
|:-----------:    |:---------------------:|
|   $1$       |   $60$ out of $80$ |
|   $2$       |   $70$ out of $100$ |

In which test did Ann do better? You **must** show your working.

solutionDetails.working:
Let's calculate the percentage score for both the tests.

$
\begin{aligned}
\text{Test } 1       &= \dfrac {60}{80} \times 100 \\\\
                     &= \dfrac {60 \times 100}{80} \\\\
                     &= \dfrac {15 \times 4 \times 20 \times 5}{20 \times 4} \\\\
                     &= \dfrac {15 \times \cancel{4} \times \cancel{20} \times 5}{\cancel{20} \times \cancel{4}} \\\\
                     &= 15 \times 5 \\\\
                     &= 75 \% \\\\
\text{Test } 2       &= \dfrac {70}{100} \times 100 \\\\
                     &= 70 \%
\end{aligned}
$

Ann did better in Test $1$.
solutionDetails.keepInMind:
- Line up digits carefully when adding or subtracting.
- Use the correct order of operations (BIDMAS).

questions.question:
The water cooler in the staff room contains $5 \ \text{litres}$ of water.

How many $200 \ \text{ml}$ glasses of water can it fill before it needs replacing?

solutionDetails.working:
The capacity of cooler is given in litres and capacity of glasses is given ml. Let's convert capacity of cooler in ml.

$
\begin{aligned}
\text{Total water}       &= 5 \ \text{litres} \\\\
                         &= 5 \times 1000 \ \text{ml} \\\\
                         &= 5000 \ \text{ml}
\end{aligned}
$

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
\text{Number of glasses} &= \dfrac {\text{Total Water in cooler}} {\text{Water in a glass}} \\\\
                         &= \dfrac {5000} {200} \\\\
                         &= \dfrac {200 \times 25} {200} \\\\
                         &= \dfrac {\cancel {200} \times 25} {\cancel {200}} \\\\
                         &= 25
\end{aligned}
$

questions.question:
A rectangle has an area of $36 \ \text{cm}^2$ and a perimeter of $26 \ \text{cm}$. Find the length and width of the rectangle.

You may use the grid to help you.


<svg width="240" height="160" viewBox="0 0 240 160" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" role="img" aria-label="Angle">
  <line x1="60" y1="120" x2="180" y2="120" stroke="black" stroke-width="2"/>
  <line x1="60" y1="120" x2="140" y2="50" stroke="black" stroke-width="2"/>
  <path d="M90 120 A30 30 0 0 1 82 97" fill="none" stroke="black" stroke-width="2"/>
  <text x="85" y="105" font-size="14">θ</text>
</svg>

solutionDetails.working:
$
\begin{aligned}
l \times w          &= 36 \\\\
2 \times (l + w)    & = 26 \\\\
l + w               &= \dfrac {26}{2} \\\\
l + w               &= \dfrac {13 \times 2}{2} \\\\
l + w               &= \dfrac {13 \times \cancel 2}{\cancel 2} \\\\
l + w               &= 13
\end{aligned}
$

We can easily infer the values by using trial and error. Let's find out $2$ numbers which meets the following critiera based on the equations above.

- Both the numbers should be smaller than $13$
- The product of the $2$ numbers is $36$
- The sum of the $2$ numbers is $13$.

Factors of $36 = 1, 2, 3, 4, 6, 9, 12, 18, 36$

| Factors   |  Sum  | Numbers $< 13$    |
|:-------:  |:----: |:---------------:  |
| $2, 18$   | $20$  |        No         |
| $3, 12$   | $15$  |       Yes         |
| $4, 9$    | $13$  |       Yes         |

A quick check shows that $4$ and $9$ meets all the criteria above.

*Note: The two equations form a quadratic equation. rtq_abbr_md_quadratic_note*

Width of the rectangle $= 4 \ \text{cm}$

Length of the rectangle $= 9 \ \text{cm}$
solutionDetails.formulasUsed:
1 m = 100 cm
Perimeter of square = 4 × side

children.question:
The number of boys who fail the test is $15$.

How many boys pass the test?

solutionDetails.working:
Let the total number of boys $= a$

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
\dfrac {3} {12} \times a            &= 15 \\\\
a                                   &= \dfrac {15 \times 12} {3} \\\\
a                                   &= \dfrac {3 \times 5 \times 12} {3} \\\\
a                                   &= \dfrac {\cancel {3} \times 5 \times 12} {\cancel {3}} \\\\
a                                   &= 5 \times 12 \\\\
a                                   &= 60
\end{aligned}
$

$
\begin{aligned}
\text{Students who passed}  &= a - 15 \\\\
                            &= 60 - 15 \\\\
                            &= 45
\end{aligned}
$

questions.question:
If $2$ apples and $1$ banana cost $\pounds 1.20$

and

$1$ apple and $2$ bananas cost $\pounds 1.35$, find the cost of an apple and a banana separately.
questions.answer:
Cost of an apple $= \pounds 0.35$

Cost of a banana $= \pounds 0.50$

solutionDetails.working:
Let the cost of an apple $= a$

Let the cost of a banana $= b$


As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
2a + b &=  1.20 \\\\
a + 2b &= 1.35
\end{aligned}
$

We have got $2$ variables and we have $2$ equations to solve them. Let's eliminate to reduce it to just one variable.

Multiply the second equation by $2$.

$
\begin{aligned}
2 \times a + 2 \times 2b     &= 2 \times 1.35 \\\\
2a + 4b                      &= 2.70
\end{aligned}
$

Subtract the first equation from the second to reduce it to one variable.

$
\begin{aligned}
2a + 4b - (2a + b)     &= 2.70 - 1.20 \\\\
2a + 4b -2a  -b        &= 1.50 \\\\
3b                     &= 1.50 \\\\
b                      &= \dfrac {1.50} {3} \\\\
b                      &= \pounds 0.50
\end{aligned}
$

Cost of a banana $= \pounds 0.50$

Let's substitute the value of $b$ in one of the initial equations to find the cost of an apple.

$
\begin{aligned}
2a + b     &=  1.20 \\\\
2a + 50    &=  1.20 \\\\
2a         &=  1.20 - 0.50 \\\\
2a         &=  0.70 \\\\
a          &= \dfrac {0.70} {2} \\\\
a          &= \pounds 0.35
\end{aligned}
$

Cost of an apple $= \pounds 0.35$

At which shop is the price of the two chairs the cheapest?

You **must** show your working.

solutionDetails.working:
Let's calculate the cheapest price of $2$ chairs from each shop.

**Shop A**

If the price is reduced by $30 \%$, then the sale price will be $100 - 30 = 70 \%$ of the original price. Using that, we get

$
\begin{aligned}
\text{Cost of 2 chairs from Shop A}     &= 70\% \times 600 \times 2 \\\\
                                        &= \dfrac{70}{100}  \times 600 \times 2  \\\\
                                        &= \dfrac{70 \times 600 \times 2}{100} \\\\
                                        &= \dfrac{70 \times 6 \cancel{0} \cancel{0} \times 2}{1\cancel{0}\cancel{0}} \\\\
                                        &= 70 \times 6 \times 2 \\\\
                                        &= \pounds 840
\end{aligned}
$

**Shop B**

If the price is reduced by $\dfrac{1}{5}$, then the sale price will be $1 - \dfrac{1}{5} = \dfrac{4}{5}$ of the original price. Using that, we get

$
\begin{aligned}
\text{Cost of } 2 \text{ chairs from Shop B}    &= \dfrac{4}{5} \times 550 \times 2 \\\\
                                                &= \dfrac{4 \times 550 \times 2}{5} \\\\
                                                &= \dfrac{4 \times 5 \times 110 \times 2}{5} \\\\
                                                &= \dfrac{4 \times \cancel{5} \times 110 \times 2}{\cancel{5}} \\\\
                                                &= 4 \times 110 \times 2 \\\\
                                                &= \pounds 880
\end{aligned}
$

**Shop C**

$
\begin{aligned}
\text{Cost of } 2 \text{ chairs from Shop C}     &= \pounds 820
\end{aligned}
$


Cheapest price $= \text{Shop C} = \pounds 820$

questions.question:
Sophie and her friends decided to raise money for charity by baking and selling cookies.
They set themselves a target of $\pounds 200$ profit to raise.

Each cookie cost them $10 \ \text{p}$ to make and they sold them for $50 \ \text{p}$.

How many cookies did they need to sell to reach their target?

solutionDetails.working:
The cookie cost is given in pence and the target is given in pounds. Let's convert the target into pence.

$
\begin{aligned}
\text {Total target}                     &= \pounds 200 \\\\
                                         &= 200 \times 100 \ \text{p} \\\\
                                         &= 20000 \ \text{p} \\\\
\text {Cost of each cookie}              &= 10 \ \text{p} \\\\
\text {Sale Price for each cookie}       &= 50 \ \text{p} \\\\
\text {Profit per cookie}                &= 50 - 10 \\\\
                                         &= 40 \ \text{p}
\end{aligned}
$

$
\begin{aligned}
\text {Number of cookies needed}             &= \dfrac {\text {Total target}} {\text {Profit per cookie}} \\\\
                                             &= \dfrac {20000} {40} \\\\
                                             &= \dfrac {40 \times 500} {40} \\\\
                                             &= \dfrac {\cancel {40} \times 500} {\cancel {40}} \\\\
                                             &= 500
\end{aligned}
$
solutionDetails.alternativeWorking:
**Alternative working 1**


Let the number of cookies $= c$

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
(50 - 10) \times c              &= 20000 \\\\
40c                             &= 20000 \\\\
c                               &= \dfrac {20000} {40} \\\\
c                               &= \dfrac {40 \times 500} {40} \\\\
c                               &= \dfrac {\cancel {40} \times 500} {\cancel {40}} \\\\
c                               &= 500
\end{aligned}
$

Number of cookies needed $= 500$

questions.question: If Tom is half his mum's age and together their ages add up to $72$, how old is Tom?

solutionDetails.working:
Let Tom's age $= a$

Tom's mum's age $=2a$

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
a + 2a      &= 72 \\\\
3a          &= 72 \\\\
a           &= \dfrac {72} {3} \\\\
a           &= \dfrac {24 \times 3} {3} \\\\
a           &= \dfrac {24 \times \cancel{3}} {\cancel{3}} \\\\
a           &= 24 \ \text{years}
\end{aligned}
$

Tom's age $= 24 \ \text{years}$
solutionDetails.keepInMind:
- Use the correct order of operations (BIDMAS).
- Write the final answer with the correct unit.

This triangle and rectangle have the same area. Find the height of the triangle.

solutionDetails.working:
As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
\dfrac {1} {2} \times 12 \times h   &= 24 \times 8 \\\\
h                                   &= \dfrac {24 \times 8 \times 2} {12} \\\\
h                                   &= \dfrac {12 \times 2 \times 8 \times 2} {12} \\\\
h                                   &= \dfrac {\cancel{12} \times 2 \times 8 \times 2} {\cancel{12}} \\\\
h                                   &= 2 \times 8 \times 2 \\\\
h                                   &= 32 \ \text{cm}
\end{aligned}
$

Height of the triangle $= 32 \ \text{cm}$.

questions.question: I wish to cover a wall measuring $2 \ \text{m}$ by $6 \ \text{m}$ in tiles which are each $50 \ \text{cm}$ by $50 \ \text{cm}$.

children.question: How many tiles will I need?

solutionDetails.working:
The wall measurement is given in $\text{meters}$ while the tile measurement is given in $\text{cm}$.

$
\begin{aligned}
\text {Number of tiles}  &= \dfrac {\text{Area of the wall}} {\text{Area of a tile}} \\\\
                         &= \dfrac {2 \ \text{m} \times 6 \ \text{m}} {50 \ \text{cm} \times 50 \ \text{cm}} \\\\
                         &= \dfrac {2 \times 100 \ \text{cm} \times 6 \times 100 \ \text{cm}} {50 \ \text{cm} \times 50 \ \text{cm}} \\\\
                         &= \dfrac {2 \times 100 \times 6 \times 100} {50  \times 50} \\\\
                         &= \dfrac {2 \times 50 \times 2 \times 6 \times 50 \times 2} {50  \times 50} \\\\
                         &= \dfrac {2 \times \cancel{50} \times 2 \times 6 \times \cancel{50} \times 2} {\cancel{50}  \times \cancel{50}} \\\\
                         &= 2 \times 2 \times 6 \times 2 \\\\
                         &= 48
\end{aligned}
$

children.question: If I now choose to use tiles which are $40 \ \text{cm}$ by $20 \ \text{cm}$ how many of these smaller tiles will I need?

solutionDetails.working:
$
\begin{aligned}
\text{Number of tiles}  &= \dfrac {\text{Area of the wall}} {\text{Area of a tile}} \\\\
                        &= \dfrac {2 \ \text{m} \times 6 \ \text{m}} {40 \ \text{cm} \times 20 \ \text{cm}} \\\\
                        &= \dfrac {2 \times 100  \ \text{cm} \times 6 \times 100 \ \text{cm}} {40 \ \text{cm} \times 20 \ \text{cm}} \\\\
                        &= \dfrac {2 \times 100 \times 6 \times 100} {40  \times 20} \\\\
                        &= \dfrac {2 \times 5 \times 20 \times 6 \times 5 \times 20} {2 \times 20  \times 20} \\\\
                        &= \dfrac {\cancel{2} \times 5 \times \cancel{20} \times 6 \times 5 \times \cancel{20}} {\cancel{2} \times \cancel{20}  \times \cancel{20}} \\\\
                        &= 5 \times 6 \times 5 \\\\
                        &= 150
\end{aligned}
$

children.question:
I am thinking of a number.

If I add $6$ then double it I get $46$.

What number am I thinking of?

solutionDetails.working:
Let the number $= a$

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
(a + 6) \times 2            &= 46 \\\\
a + 6                       &= \dfrac {46} {2} \\\\
a + 6                       &= \dfrac {23 \times 2} {2} \\\\
a + 6                       &= \dfrac {23 \times \cancel {2}} {\cancel {2}} \\\\
a + 6                       &= 23 \\\\
a                           &= 23 - 6 \\\\
a                           &= 17
\end{aligned}
$

The number I am thinking of $= 17$

Students in $6\text{C}$ were asked about their favourite sports. The results are displayed in the pie chart below.


<svg width="260" height="160" viewBox="0 0 260 160" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" role="img" aria-label="Bar chart">
  <line x1="30" y1="130" x2="240" y2="130" stroke="black" stroke-width="2"/>
  <line x1="30" y1="130" x2="30" y2="20" stroke="black" stroke-width="2"/>
  <rect x="55" y="70" width="25" height="60" fill="none" stroke="black" stroke-width="2"/>
  <rect x="100" y="50" width="25" height="80" fill="none" stroke="black" stroke-width="2"/>
  <rect x="145" y="90" width="25" height="40" fill="none" stroke="black" stroke-width="2"/>
  <rect x="190" y="35" width="25" height="95" fill="none" stroke="black" stroke-width="2"/>
</svg>


$36$ students chose hockey.

How many students chose swimming?

solutionDetails.working:
Let the total number of students in 6C $= a$

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
\dfrac{60}{360} \times a        &= 36 \\\\
a                               &= \dfrac{36 \times 360}{60} \\\\
a                               &= \dfrac{36 \times 60 \times 6}{60} \\\\
a                               &= \dfrac{36 \times \cancel{60} \times 6}{\cancel{60}} \\\\
a                               &= 36 \times 6 \\\\
a                               &= 216
\end{aligned}
$

$
\begin{aligned}
\text{Students who chose swimming}  &= \dfrac{90}{360} \times a \\\\
                                    &= \dfrac{90}{360} \times 216 \\\\
                                    &= \dfrac{90 \times 216}{360}  \\\\
                                    &= \dfrac{90 \times 4 \times 54}{90 \times 4}  \\\\
                                    &= \dfrac{\cancel{90}  \times \cancel{4} \times 54}{\cancel{90} \times \cancel{4}} \\\\
                                    &= 54
\end{aligned}
$

| $36$             | $3 + 6 = 9$   |
| $49$             | $4 + 9 = 13$  |
| $64$             | $6 + 4 = 10$  |
| $81$             | $8 + 1 = 9$   |

Square number with biggest sum of the digits $= 49$.

questions.question:
George plants a tree in his garden which is initially $180 \ \text{cm}$ high.

After the first year it has increased in height by $30\%$. During the following year its height increased by $25\%$.

How tall is the tree at the end of the second year?

solutionDetails.alternativeWorking:
**Alternative working 1**


$
\begin{aligned}
\text {Tree height after second year}  &= \dfrac {125} {100} \times \dfrac {130} {100} \times 180 \\\\
                                       &= \dfrac {125 \times 130 \times 180} {100 \times 100} \\\\
                                       &= \dfrac {125 \times 13\cancel{0} \times 18\cancel{0}} {100 \times 1\cancel{0}\cancel{0}} \\\\
                                       &= \dfrac {125 \times 13 \times 18} {100} \\\\
                                       &= \dfrac {29250} {100} \\\\
                                       &= 292.5 \ \text{cm}
\end{aligned}
$

Tree height at the end of the second year $= 292.5$ cm.

questions.question:
Mr Bevestock has a square garden which is $81 \ \text{m}^2$.

He decides to put a post every $1 \ \text{m}$ around the perimeter of his garden from which to hang decorations.

How many posts will he need?


<svg width="240" height="140" viewBox="0 0 240 140" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" role="img" aria-label="Table">
  <rect x="40" y="30" width="160" height="80" fill="none" stroke="black" stroke-width="2"/>
  <line x1="40" y1="60" x2="200" y2="60" stroke="black" stroke-width="2"/>
  <line x1="40" y1="85" x2="200" y2="85" stroke="black" stroke-width="2"/>
  <line x1="95" y1="30" x2="95" y2="110" stroke="black" stroke-width="2"/>
  <line x1="150" y1="30" x2="150" y2="110" stroke="black" stroke-width="2"/>
</svg>

solutionDetails.working:
Let the side of the square garden (in $\text{m}$) $= a$

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
a \times a                          &= 81 \\\\
a^2                                 &= 81 \\\\
a                                   &= \sqrt{81} \\\\
a                                   &= 9 \ \text{m}
\end{aligned}
$

** INFER_DESCRIPTION_NEEDS_IMPROVMENT_STARTS The $4$ corners will be counted twice, so ensure we account for that in the final calculation INFER_DESCRIPTION_NEEDS_IMPROVMENT_ENDS **

$
\begin{aligned}
\text{Number of posts needed}          &= 4 \times 9 - 4 \\\\
                                       &= 36 - 4 \\\\
                                       &= 32
\end{aligned}
$

questions.question:
A bottle of fizzy pop holds $750 \ \text{ml}$.

How many $150 \ \text{ml}$ glasses can be filled from this bottle?

solutionDetails.working:
$
\begin{aligned}
\text{Number of glasses} &= \dfrac { \text{Total drink in the bottle} } { \text{Capacity of a glass} } \\\\
                        &= \dfrac { 750 } { 150 } \\\\
                        &= \dfrac { 5 \times 150 } { 150 } \\\\
                        &= \dfrac { 5 \times \cancel{150} } { \cancel{150} } \\\\
                        &= 5
\end{aligned}
$

a           &= \dfrac{2}{10} \\\\
a           &=0.2
\end{aligned}
$

questions.question:
George had a bag full of $24$ apples.

-  He gave half of them to his Granny to make an apple pie.
-  He gave two thirds of what was left to his friends and then put the rest in the fruit bowl.

How many did he put in the fruit bowl?

solutionDetails.working:
If George gave $\dfrac {1} {2}$ to his Granny, then he is left with $1 - \dfrac {1} {2} = \dfrac {1} {2}$ of the apples. Using that, we get

$
\begin{aligned}
\text {Apples left}     &= \dfrac {1} {2} \times 24 \\\\
                        &= 12
\end{aligned}
$

If George gave $\dfrac {2} {3}$ to his friends, then he is left with $1 - \dfrac {2} {3} = \dfrac {1} {3}$ of the remaining apples. Using that, we get

$
\begin{aligned}
\text {Apples left in the fruit bowl}     &= \dfrac {1} {3} \times 12 \\\\
                                          &= 4
\end{aligned}
$

Number of apples left in his fruit bowl $= 4$
solutionDetails.alternativeWorking:
**Alternative working 1**


$
\begin{aligned}
\text {Apples left in the fruit bowl} &= \dfrac {1} {2} \times \dfrac {1} {3} \times 24 \\\\
                                      &= \dfrac {24} {2 \times 3} \\\\
                                      &= \dfrac {4 \times 2 \times 3} {2 \times 3} \\\\
                                      &= \dfrac {4 \times \cancel{2} \times \cancel{3}} {\cancel{2} \times \cancel{3}} \\\\
                                      &= 4
\end{aligned}
$

Number of apples left in the fruit bowl $= 4$
solutionDetails.keepInMind: - Check units and convert if needed.

questions.question:
Emilie is thinking of a number. If she

-  adds $2$ to it,
-  then squares it
-  and then subtracts $4$ she gets $60$.

Circle the number that Emilie was thinking of.

$4 \quad 6 \quad 30$

solutionDetails.working:
Let the number Emilie thought of $= a$

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
(a + 2 ) ^ {2} - 4     &= 60 \\\\
(a + 2 ) ^ {2}         &= 60 + 4 \\\\
(a + 2 ) ^ {2}         &= 64 \\\\
a + 2                  &= \sqrt {64} \\\\
a + 2                  &= 8 \\\\
a                      &= 8 - 2 \\\\
a                      &= 6
\end{aligned}
$

Number that Emilie thought is $= 6$.

questions.question:
Freya scored $16$ out of $20$ in her spelling test. Hannah scored $85 \%$ in her spelling test.

Who did better? You must explain your answer.

solutionDetails.working:
Let's calculate the percentage score for both.

$
\begin{aligned}
\text {Freya's score}      &= \dfrac {16} {20} \times 100 \\\\
                           &= \dfrac {16 \times 100} {20} \\\\
                           &= \dfrac {16 \times 5 \times 20} {20} \\\\
                           &= \dfrac {16 \times 5 \times \cancel{20}} {\cancel{20}} \\\\
                           &= 16 \times 5 \\\\
                           &= 80 \% \\\\
\text {Hannah's score}     &= 85 \%
\end{aligned}
$

From the calculation above, Hannah did better than Freya.

children.question: Given that $5$ people owned a white car, how many people owned a silver car?

solutionDetails.working:
Let the total number of people $= a$

As per the graph,

$
\begin{aligned}
\dfrac {30} {360} \times a          &= 5 \\\\
a                                   &= \dfrac {5 \times 360} {30} \\\\
a                                   &= \dfrac {5 \times 12 \times 30} {30} \\\\
a                                   &= \dfrac {5 \times 12 \times \cancel {30}} {\cancel {30}} \\\\
a                                   &= 5 \times 12 \\\\
a                                   &= 60
\end{aligned}
$

$
\begin{aligned}
\text {People who own silver car}   &= \dfrac {180} {360} \times a \\\\
                                    &= \dfrac {180} {360} \times 60 \\\\
                                    &= \dfrac {180 \times 60} {360} \\\\
                                    &= \dfrac {180 \times 2 \times 30} {2 \times 180} \\\\
                                    &= \dfrac {\cancel {180} \times \cancel {2} \times 30} {\cancel {2} \times \cancel {180}} \\\\
                                    &= 30
\end{aligned}
$

questions.question:
Jeff has $8$ pizzas to share between himself and his friends.

If each person is to get $\dfrac{2}{3}$ of a pizza how many friends can he feed?

solutionDetails.working:
$
\begin{aligned}
\text{Number of persons}    &= \dfrac {\text{Total pizzas}} {\text{Pizza per person}} \\\\
                            &= \dfrac {8} { \dfrac {2} {3}} \\\\
                            &= \dfrac {8 \times 3} { 2} \\\\
                            &= \dfrac {4 \times 2 \times 3} {2} \\\\
                            &= \dfrac {4 \times \cancel{2} \times 3} {\cancel{2}} \\\\
                            &= 4 \times 3 \\\\
                            &= 12 \\\\
\text{Number of friends}    &= 12 - 1 \\\\
                            &= 11
\end{aligned}
$
solutionDetails.alternativeWorking:
**Alternative working 1**


Using ratio,

$
\begin{array}{cccccccccccccc}
  & \text{pizzas}                                                           &:& \text{persons} \\\\
= & \dfrac{2}{3}                                                            &:& 1 \\\\
= & \dfrac{2}{3} \times \dfrac{3}{2}                                        &:& 1 \times \dfrac{3}{2} \\\\
= & 1                                                                       &:& \dfrac{3}{2} \\\\
= & 1 \times 8                                                              &:& \dfrac{3 \times 8}{2} \\\\
= & 8                                                                       &:& \dfrac{3 \times 4 \times 2}{2} \\\\
= & 8                                                                       &:& \dfrac{3 \times 4 \times \cancel{2}}{\cancel{2}} \\\\
= & 8                                                                       &:& 12
\end{array}
$

$
\begin{aligned}
\text{Number of persons}    &= 12 \\\\
\text{Number of friends}    &= 12 - 1 \\\\
                            &= 11
\end{aligned}
$


---

**Alternative working 2**


Let the number of persons $= a$

Using equivalent ratio,

$
\begin{aligned}
\dfrac{2}{3} \text{ pizzas} : 1 \text{ people}  &= 8 \text{ pizzas} : a \text{ persons} \\\\
\dfrac{2}{3 \times 1}                           &= \dfrac {8} {a} \\\\
a                                               &= \dfrac {8 \times 3} { 2} \\\\
a                                               &= \dfrac {4 \times 2 \times 3} {2} \\\\
a                                               &= \dfrac {4 \times \cancel{2} \times 3} {\cancel{2}} \\\\
a                                               &= 4 \times 3 \\\\
a                                               &= 12
\end{aligned}
$

$
\begin{aligned}
\text{Number of persons}    &= 12 \\\\
\text{Number of friends}    &= 12 - 1 \\\\
                            &= 11
\end{aligned}
$

questions.question:
The following is a recipe for making $12$ cupcakes.

$200 \ \text{g}$ caster sugar

$200 \ \text{g}$ butter

$180 \ \text{g}$ flour

$2$ eggs

children.question: Isaac wants to make $36$ cupcakes. How much flour should he use?

solutionDetails.working:
Let the amount of flour used $= a$

Using equivalent ratio,

$
\begin{aligned}
12 \ \text{cupcakes} : 180 \ \text{grams}       &= 36 \ \text{cupcakes} : a \ \text{grams} \\\\
\dfrac{12} {180}                                &= \dfrac {36} {a} \\\\
12 \times a                                     &= 36 \times 180 \\\\
a                                               &= \dfrac {36 \times 180} {12} \\\\
a                                               &= \dfrac {3 \times 12 \times 180} {12} \\\\
a                                               &= \dfrac {3 \times \cancel {12} \times 180} {\cancel {12}} \\\\
a                                               &= 3 \times 180 \\\\
a                                               &= 540 \ \text{g}
\end{aligned}
$

Flour used $= 540 \ \text{g}$

children.question:
Lucy has $1  \ \text{kg}$ of caster sugar.

Given that she had plenty of all the other ingredients, how many cupcakes can she make?

solutionDetails.working:
Let the number of cupcakes she can make $= a$

Using equivalent ratio,

$
\begin{aligned}
200 \ \text{g} : 12 \ \text{cupcakes}           &= 1 \ \text{kg} : a \ \text{cupcakes} \\\\
\dfrac {200 \ \text{g}} {12}                    &= \dfrac {1 \ \text{kg}} {a} \\\\
\dfrac {200 \ \text{g}} {12}                    &= \dfrac {1000 \ \text{g}} {a} \\\\
200 \times a                                    &= 1000 \times 12 \\\\
a                                               &= \dfrac {1000 \times 12} {200} \\\\
a                                               &= \dfrac {200 \times 5 \times 12} {200} \\\\
a                                               &= \dfrac {\cancel {200} \times 5 \times 12} {\cancel {200}} \\\\
a                                               &= 5 \times 12 \\\\
a                                               &= 60
\end{aligned}
$

Number of cupcakes $= 60$
solutionDetails.alternativeWorking:
**Alternative working 1**


Using ratios,

$
\begin{array}{cccccccccccccc}
  & \text{caster sugar}             &:& \text{cupcakes} \\\\
= & 200 \ \text{g}                  &:& 12 \\\\
= & 200  \times 5                   &:& 12 \times 5 \\\\
= & 1000 \ \text{g}                 &:& 60 \\\\
= & 1 \ \text{kg}                   &:& 60
\end{array}
$

Number of cupcakes $= 60$

questions.question: Fill in the gaps.

solutionDetails.working:
Let the missing number $= a$

$
\begin{aligned}
\dfrac {a} {18} + \dfrac {1} {18}     &= \dfrac {1} {2} \\\\
\dfrac {a} {18} + \dfrac {1} {18}     &= \dfrac {1 \times 9} {2 \times 9} \\\\
\dfrac {a + 1} {18}                   &= \dfrac {9} {18} \\\\
a + 1                                 &= 9 \\\\
a                                     &= 9 - 1 \\\\
a                                     &= 8
\end{aligned}
$
solutionDetails.keepInMind: - Check units and convert if needed.

solutionDetails.working:
Let the missing number $= a$

$
\begin{aligned}
\dfrac {a} {24} + \dfrac {1} {3}                       &= \dfrac {1} {2} \\\\
\dfrac {a} {24} + \dfrac {1 \times 8} {3 \times 8}     &= \dfrac {1 \times 12} {2 \times 12} \\\\
\dfrac {a} {24} + \dfrac {8} {24}                      &= \dfrac {12} {24} \\\\
\dfrac {a + 8} {24}                                    &= \dfrac {12} {24} \\\\
a + 8                                                  &= 12 \\\\
a                                                      &= 12 - 8 \\\\
a                                                      &= 4
\end{aligned}
$

|  Tickets R US | Buy $3$ get $25 \%$ off total price |
| Ticket Galore |    Buy $1$ get $2$ at $40 \%$ off   |
|   Top Ticket  |      Buy $2$ get $1$ half price     |


<svg width="200" height="200" viewBox="0 0 200 200" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" role="img" aria-label="Pie chart slice">
  <circle cx="100" cy="100" r="70" fill="none" stroke="black" stroke-width="2"/>
  <path d="M100 100 L100 30 A70 70 0 0 1 165 120 Z" fill="none" stroke="black" stroke-width="2"/>
</svg>


If I needed $3$ tickets, put the vendors in order (cheapest first).
questions.answer:
- Super Tickets
- Ticket Galore
- Tickets R US
- Top Ticket

solutionDetails.working:
Let's calculate the best price of $3$ tickets from each vendor.

**Super Tickets**

The third ticket is free when you buy $2$ tickets. So, the cost of $3$ tickets is just the cost of $2$ tickets.

$
\begin  {aligned}
\text{Cost of } 3 \text{ tickets}     &= 480 \times 2 \\\\
                                      &= \pounds 960
\end{aligned}
$

**Tickets R US**

If the total price is reduced by $25 \%$, then the sale price will be $100 - 25 = 75 \%$ of the original price. Using that, we get

$
\begin{aligned}
\text {Cost of} \ 3 \ \text{tickets}       &= 75\% \times 480 \times 3 \\\\
                                           &= \dfrac{75}{100} \times 480 \times 3 \\\\
                                           &= \dfrac{75 \times 480 \times 3}{100} \\\\
                                           &= \dfrac{25 \times 3 \times 4 \times 120 \times 3}{25 \times 4} \\\\
                                           &= \dfrac{\cancel{25} \times 3 \times \cancel{4} \times 120 \times 3}{\cancel{25} \times \cancel{4}} \\\\
                                           &= 3 \times 120 \times 3 \\\\
                                           &= \pounds 1080
\end{aligned}
$

**Ticket Galore**

If the price is reduced by $40 \%$, then the sale price will be $100 - 40 = 60 \%$ of the original price. Using that, we get

$
\begin{aligned}
\text {Cost of} \ 3 \ \text{tickets}      &= 480 + 60\% \times 480 \times 2 \\\\
                                          &= 480 + \dfrac{60}{100} \times 480 \times 2 \\\\
                                          &= 480 + \dfrac{60 \times 480 \times 2}{100} \\\\
                                          &= 480 + \dfrac{6\cancel{0} \times 48\cancel{0} \times 2}{1\cancel{0}\cancel{0}} \\\\
                                          &= 480 + 6 \times 48 \times 2 \\\\
                                          &= 480 + 576 \\\\
                                          &= \pounds 1056
\end{aligned}
$


**Top Ticket**

If the price is reduced by $\dfrac{1}{2}$, then the sale price will be $1 - \dfrac{1}{2} = \dfrac{1}{2}$ of the original price. Using that, we get

$
\begin{aligned}
\text{Cost of} \ 3 \ \text{tickets}      &= 480 \times 2 + \dfrac{1}{2} \times 480 \\\\
                                         &= 960 + \dfrac{480}{2} \\\\
                                         &= 960 + \dfrac{240 \times 2}{2} \\\\
                                         &= 960 + \dfrac{240 \times \cancel{2}}{\cancel{2}} \\\\
                                         &= 960 + 240 \\\\
                                         &= \pounds 1200
\end{aligned}
$

Using the calculation above, the vendors in order (cheapest first):

|  Vendor       | Price          |
|:-------------:|:--------------:|
| Super Tickets | $\pounds 960$  |
| Ticket Galore | $\pounds 1056$ |
| Tickets R US  | $\pounds 1080$ |
| Top Ticket    | $\pounds 1200$ |

children.question: $ \boxed{\phantom{15}} \times 30 = 240$

solutionDetails.working:
Let the missing number $= a$

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
a \times 30     &= 240 \\\\
a               &= \dfrac {240} {30} \\\\
a               &= \dfrac {30 \times 8} {30} \\\\
a               &= \dfrac {\cancel {30} \times 8} {\cancel {30}} \\\\

\end{aligned}
$

children.question: $ \boxed{\phantom{15}} \times 0.4 = 20$

solutionDetails.working:
Let the missing number $= a$

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
a \times 0.4                &= 20 \\\\
a \times \dfrac {4} {10}    &= 20 \\\\
a                           &= \dfrac {20 \times 10} {4} \\\\
a                           &= \dfrac {4 \times 5 \times 10} {4} \\\\
a                           &= \dfrac {\cancel {4} \times 5 \times 10} {\cancel {4}} \\\\
a                           &= 5 \times 10  \\\\
a                           &= 50
\end{aligned}
$

A teacher is making toffee apples for his class 'Hallowe'en party.

He needs to make $24$ toffee apples.

He uses the following recipe which makes $8$ toffee apples.

**Ingredients**

$8$ red apples

$400 \ \text{g}$ caster sugar

$1$ tsp lemon juice

$4$ tbsp golden syrup

red or black food colouring

children.question: How many tablespoons of golden syrup will he need?

solutionDetails.working:
Let the count of tablespoons needed $= a$

Using equivalent ratio,

$
\begin{aligned}
8 \ \text{toffee apples} : 4 \ \text{tbsp}      &= 24 \ \text{toffee apples} : a \ \text{tbsp} \\\\
\dfrac{8} {4}                                   &= \dfrac {24} {a} \\\\
8 \times a                                      &= 24 \times 4 \\\\
a                                               &= \dfrac {24 \times 4} {8} \\\\
a                                               &= \dfrac {3 \times 8 \times 4} {8} \\\\
a                                               &= \dfrac {3 \times \cancel {8} \times 4} {\cancel {8}} \\\\
a                                               &= 3 \times 4 \\\\
a                                               &= 12 \ \text{tbsp}
\end{aligned}
$

Golden syrup needed $= 12 \ \text{tbsp}$
solutionDetails.alternativeWorking:
**Alternative working 1**


Using ratios,

$
\begin{array}{cccccccccccccc}
  & \text{toffee apples}            &:&     \text{golden syrup} \\\\
= & 8                               &:&     4 \ \text{tbsp} \\\\
= & 8  \times 3                     &:&     4 \times 3 \\\\
= & 24                              &:&     12 \ \text{tbsp}
\end{array}
$

Golden syrup needed $= 12 \ \text{tbsp}$

questions.question: Arthur's twin sisters are $4 \ \text {years}$  older than him. Altogether their ages add up to $77$. How old is Arthur?

solutionDetails.working:
Let Arthur's age $= a$

His twin sisters' ages $= a + 4$ and $a + 4$

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
a + (a + 4) + (a + 4)   &= 77 \\\\
3a + 8                  &= 77 \\\\
3a                      &= 77 - 8 \\\\
3a                      &= 69 \\\\
a                       &= \dfrac{69}{3} \\\\
a                       &= \dfrac{23 \times 3}{3} \\\\
a                       &= \dfrac{23 \times \cancel{3}}{\cancel{3}} \\\\
a                       &= 23 \ \text{years}
\end{aligned}
$

questions.question:
Put these fractions in ascending order of size, show workings.

$\dfrac{3}{5}$ of $30$

$\dfrac{7}{10}$ of $20$

$\dfrac{2}{3}$ of $24$

solutionDetails.working:
$
\begin{aligned}
\text {First} &= \dfrac{3}{5} \ \text{of} \ 30 \\\\
              &= \dfrac{3}{5} \times 30 \\\\
              &= \dfrac{3 \times 6 \times 5}{5} \\\\
              &= \dfrac{3 \times 6 \times \cancel{5}}{\cancel{5}} \\\\
              &= 18 \\\\
\text {Second}  &= \dfrac{7}{10} \ \text{of} \ 20 \\\\
                &= \dfrac{7}{10} \times 20 \\\\
                &= \dfrac{7 \times 20}{10} \\\\
                &= \dfrac{7 \times 2 \times 10}{10} \\\\
                &= \dfrac{7 \times 2 \times \cancel{10}}{\cancel{10}} \\\\
                &= 14 \\\\
\text {Third}  &= \dfrac{2}{3} \ \text{of} \ 24 \\\\
&= \dfrac{2}{3} \times 24 \\\\
&= \dfrac{2 \times 24}{3} \\\\
&= \dfrac{2 \times 8 \times 3}{3} \\\\
&= \dfrac{2 \times 8 \times \cancel{3}}{\cancel{3}} \\\\
&= 16
\end{aligned}
$

Arrange the results in ascending order.

$
\begin{aligned}
& 14 < 16 < 18 \\\\
& \dfrac{7}{10} \ \text{of} \ 20 < \dfrac{2}{3} \ \text{of} \ 24 < \dfrac{3}{5} \ \text{of} \ 30
\end{aligned}
$
solutionDetails.keepInMind: - Show each step clearly; don’t do too much in one line.

solutionDetails.keepInMind: - Line up digits carefully when adding or subtracting.

children.question:
Solve the following equation to find $b$.

$2b - 25 = 41$

solutionDetails.working:
As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
2b - 25     &= 41 \\\\
2b          &= 41 + 25 \\\\
2b          &= 66 \\\\
b           &= \dfrac {66} {2} \\\\
b           &= \dfrac {33 \times 2} {2} \\\\
b           &= \dfrac {33 \times \cancel {2}} {\cancel {2}} \\\\
b           &= 33
\end{aligned}
$

- Check units and convert if needed.
- Line up digits carefully when adding or subtracting.

questions.question:
What fraction of these numbers are below the median?

$2 \quad 7 \quad 10 \quad 5 \quad 4$

solutionDetails.working:
Let's arrange the numbers in ascending order.

$
\begin{aligned}
\text{Numbers} &= 2, \quad 7, \quad 10, \quad 5, \quad 4 \\\\
\text{Ordered numbers} &= 2, \quad 4, \quad \rtq_katex_color_info{5}, \quad 7, \quad 10 \\\\
\text{Median} &= 5
\end{aligned}
$

Numbers below the median are $2$ and $4$.

Fraction of numbers below the median $= \dfrac{2}{5}$

questions.question:
Given that two teas and a coffee cost $ \pounds 2.50$ and one tea and three coffees cost $ \pounds 3.50$.

How much does a single coffee cost?

solutionDetails.working:
Let the cost of a cup of tea $= t$

Let the cost of a cup of coffee $= c$

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
2t + c &= 2.50 \\\\
t + 3c &= 3.50
\end{aligned}
$

We have got $2$ variables and we have $2$ equations to solve them. Let's eliminate to reduce it to just one variable.

Multiply the second equation by $2$.

$
\begin{aligned}
2 \times t + 2 \times 3c &= 2 \times 3.50 \\\\
2t + 6c &= 7.00
\end{aligned}
$

Subtract the first equation from the second to reduce it to one variable.

$
\begin{aligned}
(2t + 6c) - (2t + c) &= 7.00 - 2.50 \\\\
2t + 6c - 2t - c &= 4.50 \\\\
5c &= 4.50 \\\\
c &= \dfrac {4.50} {5} \\\\
c &= \pounds 0.90
\end{aligned}
$

Cost of a cup of coffee $= \pounds 0.90$.

1 kg = 1000 g

questions.question:
A bridge is built across a river. One quarter of the bridge is over the left bank of the river and one third of the bridge is over the right bank.

The river is $84 \ \text{m}$ wide.

How long is the bridge?

solutionDetails.working:
Let the length of the bridge $= L \ \text{m}$

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
\text{Portions over banks}  &= \dfrac{L}{4} + \dfrac{L}{3} \\\\
                            &= \dfrac{3L}{4 \times 3} + \dfrac{4L}{3 \times 4} \\\\
                            &= \dfrac{3L}{12} + \dfrac{4L}{12} \\\\
                            &= \dfrac{7L}{12} \\\\
\text{Portion over river}   &= L - \dfrac{7L}{12} \\\\
                            &= \dfrac{12L}{12} - \dfrac{7L}{12} \\\\
                            &= \dfrac{5L}{12} \\\\
                            &= \dfrac{5 \times 84}{12}  \\\\
                            &= \dfrac{5 \times 7 \times 12}{12}  \\\\
                            &= \dfrac{5 \times 7 \times \cancel{12}}{\cancel{12}}  \\\\
                            &= 35 \ \text{m}
\end{aligned}
$

- Write the final answer with the correct unit.

questions.question: Write down all the numbers between $50$ and $150$ that have an odd number of factors?

solutionDetails.working:
Let's list all the perfect squares between $50$ and $150$.

| Number | Calculation | Result |
|:------:|:-----------:|:-------:|
| $8$    | $8 \times 8$   | $64 < 150$ |
| $9$    | $9 \times 9$   | $81 < 150$ |
| $10$   | $10 \times 10$ | $100 < 150$ |
| $11$   | $11 \times 11$ | $121 < 150$ |
| $12$   | $12 \times 12$ | $144 < 150$ |
| $\rtq_katex_color_wrong_answer{13}$   | $\rtq_katex_color_wrong_answer{13 \times 13}$ | $\rtq_katex_color_wrong_answer{169 > 150}$ |

From the table above, all the perfect squares that are less than $150$ and greater than $50$ are $64, \ 81, \ 100, \ 121,$ and $144$.

questions.question:
Decrease $\pounds 44$ by $10\%$.

- $\pounds 39.60$
- $\pounds 4.40$
- $\pounds 48.40$
- $\pounds 34$

solutionDetails.working:
If the amount is reduced by $10 \%$, then the reduced value will be $100 - 10 = 90 \%$ of the original value. Using that, we get

$
\begin{aligned}
&= 90 \% \ \text {of} \ \text 44 \\\\
&= \dfrac {90} {100} \times 44 \\\\
&= \dfrac {90 \times 44} {100} \\\\
&= \dfrac {3960} {100} \\\\
&= \pounds 39.60
\end{aligned}
$
solutionDetails.keepInMind: - Show each step clearly; don’t do too much in one line.

questions.question:
A box contains bags of crisps.

Each bag of crisps weighs $25 \ \text{grams}$.

Altogether, the bags of crisps inside weigh $1 \ \text{kg}$.

How many bags of crisps are inside the box?

solutionDetails.working:
Let the number of bags of crisps $= b$


The weight of box is given in kg and weight of crisp bag is given in grams. Lets convert weight of box in grams.

$
\begin{aligned}
\text{Total weight of the bags}         &= 1 \ \text{kg} \\\\
                                        &= 1 \times 1000 \ \text{grams} \\\\
                                        &= 1000 \ \text{grams}
\end{aligned}
$

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
b \times 25                 &= 1000 \\\\
b                           &= \dfrac {1000} {25} \\\\
b                           &= \dfrac {25 \times 40} {25} \\\\
b                           &= \dfrac {\cancel {25} \times 40} {\cancel {25}} \\\\
b                           &= 40
\end{aligned}
$

Number of bags of crisps inside the box $= 40$

questions.question:
A tin of paint can cover $45 \ \text{m}^2$ of wall. The school hall has $652 \ \text{m}^2$ of wall to paint.

How many tins of paint are needed?

solutionDetails.working:
$
\begin{aligned}
\text {Number of tins needed}  &= \dfrac {\text{Total area of the hall}} {\text{Area covered by a tin}} \\\\
                               &= \dfrac {652} {45} \\\\
                               &= 14.48 \\\\
                               &= 15
\end{aligned}
$
solutionDetails.keepInMind:
- Use the correct order of operations (BIDMAS).
- When dividing by a fraction, multiply by the reciprocal.

Tile $4$ touches two other tiles.
Write the coordinates of the points where tile $4$ touches two other tiles.
Write the coordinates of the points where tile $17$ touches two other tiles.

I have $30$ tiles to make a pattern on a grid. The pattern is a series of squares.


<svg width="200" height="200" viewBox="0 0 200 200" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" role="img" aria-label="Pie chart slice">
  <circle cx="100" cy="100" r="70" fill="none" stroke="black" stroke-width="2"/>
  <path d="M100 100 L100 30 A70 70 0 0 1 165 120 Z" fill="none" stroke="black" stroke-width="2"/>
</svg>


I have used some of the $30$ tiles to make my pattern.
Do I have enough tiles to make the next square, of side length $4?$
Show working to explain your answer.

solutionDetails.working:
$
\begin{aligned}
\text {Tiles needed}        &= 4 \times 4 \\\\
                            &= 16 \\\\
\text {Tiles used}          &= 1^2 + 2^2 + 3^2 \\\\
                            &= 1 + 4 + 9 \\\\
                            &= 14 \\\\
\text {Tiles Left}          &= 30 - 14 \\\\
                            &= 16
\end{aligned}
$

There are enough tiles to make the next square.
solutionDetails.keepInMind:
- Show each step clearly; don’t do too much in one line.
- Line up digits carefully when adding or subtracting.

children.question:
The **perimeter** of a regular hexagon is $42a + 18$.
Write an expression for the lengths of one of its sides.


<svg width="320" height="80" viewBox="0 0 320 80" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" role="img" aria-label="Number line">
  <line x1="20" y1="40" x2="300" y2="40" stroke="black" stroke-width="2"/>
  <line x1="20" y1="32" x2="20" y2="48" stroke="black" stroke-width="2"/>
            <text x="20" y="68" text-anchor="middle" font-size="14">0</text>
<line x1="76" y1="32" x2="76" y2="48" stroke="black" stroke-width="2"/>
            <text x="76" y="68" text-anchor="middle" font-size="14">1</text>
<line x1="132" y1="32" x2="132" y2="48" stroke="black" stroke-width="2"/>
            <text x="132" y="68" text-anchor="middle" font-size="14">2</text>
<line x1="188" y1="32" x2="188" y2="48" stroke="black" stroke-width="2"/>
            <text x="188" y="68" text-anchor="middle" font-size="14">3</text>
<line x1="244" y1="32" x2="244" y2="48" stroke="black" stroke-width="2"/>
            <text x="244" y="68" text-anchor="middle" font-size="14">4</text>
<line x1="300" y1="32" x2="300" y2="48" stroke="black" stroke-width="2"/>
            <text x="300" y="68" text-anchor="middle" font-size="14">5</text>
</svg>

solutionDetails.working:
$
\begin{aligned}
\text{Length of one side}   &= \dfrac {\text{Perimeter}} {\text{Number of sides}} \\\\
                            &= \dfrac {42a + 18} {6} \\\\
                            &= \dfrac {6 \times 7a + 6 \times 3} {6} \\\\
                            &= \dfrac {6 \times (7a + 3)} {6} \\\\
                            &= \dfrac {\cancel 6 \times (7a + 3)} {\cancel 6} \\\\
                            &= 7a + 3
\end{aligned}
$

Length of one side $= 7a + 3$.
solutionDetails.keepInMind: - Line up digits carefully when adding or subtracting.

children.question:
The **perimeter** of a different regular polygon is $75b - 20$.
The length of one of its sides is $15b - 4$.
How many sides does the regular polygon have?

solutionDetails.working:
$
\begin{aligned}
\text{Number of sides}   &= \dfrac {\text{Perimeter}} {\text{Length of one side}} \\\\
                            &= \dfrac {75b - 20} {15b - 4} \\\\
                            &= \dfrac {5 \times 15b - 5 \times 4} {15b - 4} \\\\
                            &= \dfrac {5 \times (15b - 4)} {15b - 4} \\\\
                            &= \dfrac {5 \times \cancel {(15b - 4)}} {\cancel {15b - 4}} \\\\
                            &= 5
\end{aligned}
$

Number of sides $= 5$.

questions.question:
A cube measuring $3 \ \text{cm} \times 3 \ \text{cm} \times 3 \ \text{cm}$ is made up of small cubes and has a
$1 \ \text{cm} \times 1 \ \text{cm}$ square hole pushed right through the centre of each face so that you can see straight through the cube from every side.


<svg width="320" height="80" viewBox="0 0 320 80" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" role="img" aria-label="Number line">
  <line x1="20" y1="40" x2="300" y2="40" stroke="black" stroke-width="2"/>
  <line x1="20" y1="32" x2="20" y2="48" stroke="black" stroke-width="2"/>
            <text x="20" y="68" text-anchor="middle" font-size="14">0</text>
<line x1="76" y1="32" x2="76" y2="48" stroke="black" stroke-width="2"/>
            <text x="76" y="68" text-anchor="middle" font-size="14">1</text>
<line x1="132" y1="32" x2="132" y2="48" stroke="black" stroke-width="2"/>
            <text x="132" y="68" text-anchor="middle" font-size="14">2</text>
<line x1="188" y1="32" x2="188" y2="48" stroke="black" stroke-width="2"/>
            <text x="188" y="68" text-anchor="middle" font-size="14">3</text>
<line x1="244" y1="32" x2="244" y2="48" stroke="black" stroke-width="2"/>
            <text x="244" y="68" text-anchor="middle" font-size="14">4</text>
<line x1="300" y1="32" x2="300" y2="48" stroke="black" stroke-width="2"/>
            <text x="300" y="68" text-anchor="middle" font-size="14">5</text>
</svg>


How many small cubes are used to make this shape?

solutionDetails.working:
$
\begin{aligned}
\text{Smaller cubes without removing}   &= \dfrac {\text{Volume of the big cube}} {\text{Volume of 1 small cube}} \\\\
                                        &= \dfrac {3 \times 3 \times 3} {1 \times 1 \times 1} \\\\
                                        &= 27 \\\\
\text{Cubes to remove}                  &= \text{Cube on each face} + \text{Cube at the center} \\\\
                                        &= 6 + 1 \\\\
                                        &= 7 \\\\
\text{Cubes needed}                     &= 27 - 7 \\\\
                                        &= 20
\end{aligned}
$
solutionDetails.keepInMind: - Show each step clearly; don’t do too much in one line.

For one of the spinners, the probability of spinning grey is $\dfrac{3}{4}$.

solutionDetails.working:
$
\begin{aligned}
\text{P(spinning grey in A)}       &= \dfrac {2} {3} \\\\
\text{P(spinning grey in B)}       &= \dfrac {3} {4} \\\\
\text{P(spinning grey in C)}       &= \dfrac {3} {5} \\\\
\text{P(spinning grey in D)}       &= \dfrac {5} {8} \\\\
\text{P(spinning grey in E)}       &= \dfrac {2} {6} \\\\
                                   &= \dfrac {2} {3 \times 2} \\\\
                                   &= \dfrac {\cancel {2}} {3 \times \cancel {2}} \\\\
                                   &= \dfrac {1} {3}
\end{aligned}
$

Spinner B

children.question:
For two of the spinners, the probability of spinning grey is more than $60\%$ but less than $70\%$.

Which two spinners are these?

solutionDetails.working:
$
\begin{aligned}
\text{P(spinning grey in A)}       &= \dfrac {2} {3} \times 100 \\\\
                                   &= \dfrac {200} {3} \\\\
                                   &= 66.66 \% \\\\
\text{P(spinning grey in B)}       &= \dfrac {3} {4} \times 100 \\\\
                                   &= \dfrac {3 \times 100} {4} \\\\
                                   &= \dfrac {3 \times 25 \times 4} {4} \\\\
                                   &= \dfrac {3 \times 25 \times \cancel{4}} {\cancel{4}} \\\\
                                   &= 3 \times 25  \\\\
                                   &= 75 \% \\\\
\text{P(spinning grey in C)}       &= \dfrac {3} {5} \times 100 \\\\
                                   &= \dfrac {3 \times 100} {5} \\\\
                                   &= \dfrac {3 \times 20 \times 5} {5} \\\\
                                   &= \dfrac {3 \times 20 \times \cancel{5}} {\cancel{5}} \\\\
                                   &= 3 \times 20  \\\\
                                   &= 60 \% \\\\
\text{P(spinning grey in D)}       &= \dfrac {5} {8} \times 100 \\\\
                                   &= \dfrac {5 \times 100} {8} \\\\
                                   &= \dfrac {5 \times 25 \times 4} {4 \times 2} \\\\
                                   &= \dfrac {5 \times 25 \times \cancel{4}} {\cancel{4} \times 2} \\\\
                                   &= \dfrac {5 \times 25} {2} \\\\
                                   &= \dfrac {125} {2} \\\\
                                   &= 62.5 \% \\\\
\text{P(spinning grey in E)}       &= \dfrac {1} {3} \times 100 \\\\
                                   &= \dfrac {100} {3} \\\\
                                   &= 33.33 \%
\end{aligned}
$

Spinner A, Spinner D

children.question: What fraction of students said “Comedy”?

$20$ students said “Horror”.

Work out the total number of students that Betty asked.

solutionDetails.working:
Let the total number of students $= a$

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
\dfrac {120} {360} \times a     &= 20 \\\\
a                               &= \dfrac {20 \times 360} {120} \\\\
a                               &= \dfrac {20 \times 3 \times 120} {120} \\\\
a                               &= \dfrac {20 \times 3 \times \cancel {120}} {\cancel {120}} \\\\
a                               &= 20 \times 3 \\\\
a                               &= 60
\end{aligned}
$

Total number of students $= 60$

questions.question: $\pounds 6 - \pounds 3.24 = {?}$

Mel has 27 marbles. She gives $\dfrac{1}{3}$ of them to Vix
and a half of the rest to Sarah. How many are left?

solutionDetails.working:
$
\begin{aligned}
\text {Marbles left}            &=  \text {Total Marbles} -  \text {Marbles Vix got} - \text {Marbles Sarah got} \\\\
                                &=  27 -  \dfrac {1} {3} \times 27 - \dfrac {1} {4} \times 180 \\\\
                                &=  180 -  \dfrac {2 \times 180} {5}  - \dfrac {180} {4}  \\\\
                                &=  180 -  \dfrac {2 \times 36 \times 5} {5}  - \dfrac {45 \times 4} {4}  \\\\
                                &=  180 -  \dfrac {2 \times 36 \times \cancel{5}} {\cancel{5}}  - \dfrac{45 \times \cancel{4}} {\cancel{4}}  \\\\
                                &=  180 -  2 \times 36 - 45  \\\\
                                &=  180 -  72 - 45  \\\\
                                &=  63
\end{aligned}
$
solutionDetails.keepInMind: - Check units and convert if needed.

solutionDetails.keepInMind:
- When dividing by a fraction, multiply by the reciprocal.
- Check units and convert if needed.

solutionDetails.working:
Let the missing number $= a$

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
82 - 27  &= 5 \times a \\\\
5a       &= 82 - 27 \\\\
5a       &= 55 \\\\
a        &= \dfrac {55} {5} \\\\
a        &= \dfrac {5 \times 11} {5} \\\\
a        &= \dfrac {\cancel {5} \times 11} {\cancel {5} } \\\\
a        &= 11
\end{aligned}
$
solutionDetails.keepInMind:

- Line up digits carefully when adding or subtracting.

questions.question: Small egg boxes can hold six eggs. How many egg boxes are needed to hold $50$ eggs?

solutionDetails.working:
Let the number of egg boxes needed $= a$

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
a \times 6                          &= 50 \\\\
a                                   &= \dfrac {50} {6} \\\\
a                                   &= \dfrac {25 \times 2} {3 \times 2} \\\\
a                                   &= \dfrac {25 \times \cancel 2} {3 \times \cancel 2} \\\\
a                                   &= \dfrac {25} {3} \\\\
a                                   &= 8 \dfrac {1} {3} \\\\
a                                   &= 9
\end{aligned}
$

Number of egg boxes needed $= 9$.

questions.question: Two angles of a triangle are $49 \degree$ and $52 \degree$. What is the third angle?

solutionDetails.working:
Let the third angle $= a$

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
49 + 52 + a    &= 180 \\\\
101 + a        &= 180 \\\\
a              &= 180 - 101 \\\\
a              &= 79 \degree
\end{aligned}
$

Third angle $= 79 \degree$

questions.question:
A triangle has a base of $6 \ \text{cm}$ and a height
of $4 \ \text{cm}$. It has the same area as another
triangle of base length $8 \ \text{cm}$. How tall is the triangle?

solutionDetails.working:
Let the height of the second triangle $= a$

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
\dfrac {1} {2} \times 8 \ \times a        &= \dfrac {1} {2} \times 6 \ \times 4 \\\\
\dfrac {8} {2} \times a                   &= \dfrac {1} {2} \times 24 \\\\
a                                         &= \dfrac {24} {2} \times \dfrac {2} {8} \\\\
a                                         &= \dfrac {24 \times 2} {2 \times 8} \\\\
a                                         &= \dfrac {3 \times 8 \times 2} {2 \times 8} \\\\
a                                         &= \dfrac {3 \times \cancel {8} \times \cancel {2}} {\cancel {2} \times \cancel {8}} \\\\
a                                         &= 3 \ \text{cm}
\end{aligned}
$

Triangle is $3 \ \text{cm}$ tall.
solutionDetails.keepInMind: - Line up digits carefully when adding or subtracting.

questions.question:
What is the missing number in this number sentence?

$3.6 \times {?} = 1.8 \times 7$

solutionDetails.working:
Let the missing number $= a$

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
3.6 \times a                 &= 1.8 \times 7  \\\\
a                            &= \dfrac {1.8 \times 7} {3.6}  \\\\
a                            &= \dfrac {18 \times 7 \times 10} {36 \times 10} \\\\
a                            &= \dfrac {18 \times 7 \times 10} {18 \times 2 \times 10} \\\\
a                            &= \dfrac {\cancel {18} \times 7 \times \cancel {10}} {\cancel {18} \times 2 \times \cancel {10}} \\\\
a                            &= \dfrac {7} {2} \\\\
a                            &= 3.5
\end{aligned}
$

The missing number $= 3.5$

questions.question:
The mean of two numbers is six. One of the numbers
is minus two. What is the other number?

solutionDetails.working:
Let the other number $= a$

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
\dfrac {a + (-2)} {2}   &= 6 \\\\
a - 2                   &= 6 \times 2 \\\\
a - 2                   &= 12 \\\\
a                       &= 12 + 2 \\\\
a                       &= 14
\end{aligned}
$
solutionDetails.keepInMind:
- Write the final answer with the correct unit.
- Show each step clearly; don’t do too much in one line.

questions.question: Write the missing numbers in the boxes.

children.question: $4 \times \boxed{\phantom{555}} + 20 = 180$

solutionDetails.working:
Let the missing number $= a$.

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
4 \times a + 20     &= 180  \\\\
4a                  &= 180 - 20 \\\\
4a                  &= 160 \\\\
a                   &= \dfrac {160} {4} \\\\
a                   &= \dfrac {40 \times 4} {4} \\\\
a                   &= \dfrac {40 \times \cancel {4}} {\cancel {4}} \\\\
a                   &= 40
\end{aligned}
$
solutionDetails.keepInMind: - Line up digits carefully when adding or subtracting.

children.question: $4 \times 20 + \boxed{\phantom{555}} = 180$

solutionDetails.working:
Let the missing number $= a$.

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
4 \times 20 + a &= 180  \\\\
80 + a          &= 180 \\\\
a               &= 180 - 80 \\\\
a               &= 100
\end{aligned}
$
solutionDetails.keepInMind:
- Line up digits carefully when adding or subtracting.
- When dividing by a fraction, multiply by the reciprocal.

children.question: $4 \times \boxed{\phantom{555}} - 20 = 180$

solutionDetails.working:
Let the missing number $= a$.

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
 4 \times a - 20 &= 180 \\\\
4a               &= 180 + 20 \\\\
4a               &= 200 \\\\
 a               &= \dfrac {200} {4} \\\\
 a               &= \dfrac {50 \times 4} {4} \\\\
 a               &= \dfrac {50 \times \cancel{4}} {\cancel{4}} \\\\
 a               &=  50
\end{aligned}
$
solutionDetails.keepInMind:
- Line up digits carefully when adding or subtracting.
- Show each step clearly; don’t do too much in one line.

children.question:
$46 \times 44 = 2024$

$46 \times 22 = \text{\textunderscore \textunderscore \textunderscore}$

$600 \div 24 = 25$

$600 \div \text{\textunderscore \textunderscore \textunderscore} = 50$

solutionDetails.working:
Let the missing  number $= a$

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
600 \div 24              &= 25 \\\\
\dfrac{600}{24} \times 2 &= 25 \times 2 \\\\
\dfrac{600 \times 2}{24} &= 50 \\\\
\dfrac{600 \times 2}{12 \times 2} &= 50 \\\\
\dfrac{600 \times \cancel{2}}{12 \times \cancel{2}} &= 50 \\\\
\dfrac{600}{12}          &= 50 \\\\
600 \div \boxed{12}      &= 50 \\\\
\end{aligned}
$
solutionDetails.keepInMind: - Write the final answer with the correct unit.

Expression
- $5k$

|               |         Area         |      Perimenter    |

| Square $A$    | $\ldots \ \text{cm}^2$ | $\ldots \ \text{cm}$ |

| Square $C$    | $\ldots \ \text{cm}^2$ | $\ldots \ \text{cm}$ |

solutionDetails.alternativeWorking:
**Alternative working 1**


As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
\text {Width of the rectangle B}        &= 8 \ \text{cm} \\\\
\text {Length of the rectangle B}       &= \dfrac {8} {2} \\\\
                                        &= \dfrac {2 \times 4} {2} \\\\
                                        &= \dfrac {\cancel {2} \times 4} {\cancel {2}} \\\\
                                        &= 4 \ \text{cm} \\\\
\text {Area of the rectangle B}         &= 4 \times 8 \\\\
                                        &= 32 \ \text{cm}^2 \\\\
\text {Perimeter of the rectangle B}    &= 2 \times (4 + 8) \\\\
                                        &= 2 \times 12 \\\\
                                        &= 24 \ \text{cm}
\end{aligned}
$


---

**Alternative working 2**


As per the diagram,

$
\begin{aligned}
\text {Side of the square}              &= \dfrac {8} {2} \\\\
                                        &= \dfrac {2 \times 4} {2} \\\\
                                        &= \dfrac {\cancel {2} \times 4} {\cancel {2}} \\\\
                                        &= 4 \ \text{cm} \\\\
\text {Area of the square A}            &= 4 \times 4 \\\\
                                        &= 16 \ \text{cm}^2 \\\\
\text {Perimeter of the square A}       &= 4 \times 4 \\\\
                                        &= 16 \ \text{cm}
\end{aligned}
$
solutionDetails.keepInMind: - Write the final answer with the correct unit.

solutionDetails.working:

\text {A}           &= 750 \ \text {ml} \\\\

                    &= 250 \ \text {ml}
\end{aligned}
$

Container A holds $250 \ \text {ml}$ more than container B.

questions.question:
Lisa has some boxes that are all cubes of the same size.

She uses four of the boxes to make a pile with a height of $72 \ \text{cm}$.

She puts one more box on top of the pile.


<svg width="260" height="160" viewBox="0 0 260 160" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" role="img" aria-label="Bar chart">
  <line x1="30" y1="130" x2="240" y2="130" stroke="black" stroke-width="2"/>
  <line x1="30" y1="130" x2="30" y2="20" stroke="black" stroke-width="2"/>
  <rect x="55" y="70" width="25" height="60" fill="none" stroke="black" stroke-width="2"/>
  <rect x="100" y="50" width="25" height="80" fill="none" stroke="black" stroke-width="2"/>
  <rect x="145" y="90" width="25" height="40" fill="none" stroke="black" stroke-width="2"/>
  <rect x="190" y="35" width="25" height="95" fill="none" stroke="black" stroke-width="2"/>
</svg>


Work out the height of the pile of **five** boxes.

solutionDetails.working:
As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
\text{Height of the pile of 5 boxes}            &= 5 \times \dfrac {72} {4} \\\\
                                                &= \dfrac {5 \times 72} {4} \\\\
                                                &= \dfrac {5 \times 18 \times 4} {4} \\\\
                                                &= \dfrac {5 \times 18 \times \cancel 4} {\cancel 4} \\\\
                                                &= 5 \times 18 \\\\
                                                &= 90 \ \text{cm}
\end{aligned}
$

questions.question: In a bag there are only red, blue and green counters.

children.question:
I am going to take a counter out of the bag at random.

Complete the table below.

|  Colours of counters | Number of counters  | Probability  |
|:------------: |:------------: |:------------: |
|      Red      |     $6$       |               |
|      Blue      |              | $\dfrac{1} {5}$ |
|     Green     |     $6$       |               |

solutionDetails.working:
Let the number of blue counters = b

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
\dfrac{b}{6 + 6 + b}    &= \dfrac {1} {5} \\\\
\dfrac{b}{12 + b}       &= \dfrac {1} {5} \\\\
5b                      &= 12 + b \\\\
5b - b                  &= 12 \\\\
4b                      &= 12 \\\\
b                       &= \dfrac {12} {4} \\\\
                        &= \dfrac {4 \times 3} {4} \\\\
                        &= \dfrac {\cancel {4} \times 3} {\cancel {4}} \\\\
                        &= 3 \\\\
\text{P(red)}           &= \dfrac {6} {6 + 3 + 6} \\\\
                        &= \dfrac {6} {15} \\\\
                        &= \dfrac {2 \times 3} {3 \times 5} \\\\
                        &= \dfrac {2 \times \cancel{3}} {\cancel{3} \times 5} \\\\
                        &= \dfrac {2} {5} \\\\
\text{P(green)}         &= \dfrac {6} {6 + 3 + 6} \\\\
                        &= \dfrac {6} {15} \\\\
                        &= \dfrac {2 \times 3} {3 \times 5} \\\\
                        &= \dfrac {2 \times \cancel{3}} {\cancel{3} \times 5} \\\\
                        &= \dfrac {2} {5}
\end{aligned}
$

| Counter       |  Number      | Probability      |
|:------------: |:------------:|:----------------:|
|      Red      |     $6$      | $\dfrac{2} {5}$  |
|      Blue     |     $3$      | $\dfrac{1} {5}$  |
|     Green     |     $6$      | $\dfrac{2} {5}$  |
solutionDetails.keepInMind:
- When dividing by a fraction, multiply by the reciprocal.
- Check units and convert if needed.

questions.question:
Gita threw three darts.

Use the information in the box to work out what numbers she threw.

- The lowest number was $10$.
- The range was $10$.
- The mean was $15$.

solutionDetails.working:
Let the highest number $= h$

Let the middle number $= m$

As per the question, equating for range,

$
\begin{aligned}
10                  &= h - 10 \\\\
h                   &= 10 + 10 \\\\
h                   &= 20
\end{aligned}
$

Highest number $= 20$

As per the question, equating for mean,

$
\begin{aligned}
\dfrac {h + m + 10} {3}     &= 15 \\\\
\dfrac {20 + m + 10} {3}    &= 15 \\\\
30 + m                      &= 15 \times 3 \\\\
30 + m                      &= 45 \\\\
m                           &= 45 - 30 \\\\
m                           &= 15
\end{aligned}
$

Middle number $= 15$
solutionDetails.formulasUsed:
Area of square = side²
Percentage = (part ÷ whole) × 100%

children.question:
The perimeter of a regular hexagon is $42a + 18$.

Write an expression for the length of one of its sides.


<svg width="240" height="160" viewBox="0 0 240 160" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" role="img" aria-label="Angle">
  <line x1="60" y1="120" x2="180" y2="120" stroke="black" stroke-width="2"/>
  <line x1="60" y1="120" x2="140" y2="50" stroke="black" stroke-width="2"/>
  <path d="M90 120 A30 30 0 0 1 82 97" fill="none" stroke="black" stroke-width="2"/>
  <text x="85" y="105" font-size="14">θ</text>
</svg>

solutionDetails.working:
Let the side of the hexagon $= s$

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
6 \times s  &= 42a + 18 \\\\
6s          &= 42a + 18 \\\\
s           &= \dfrac {42a + 18} {6} \\\\
s           &= \dfrac {6 \times 7a + 6 \times 3} {6} \\\\
s           &= \dfrac {6 \times (7a + 3)} {6} \\\\
s           &= \dfrac {\cancel {6} \times (7a + 3)} {\cancel {6}} \\\\
s           &= 7a + 3
\end{aligned}
$

Length of the one side of hexagon $= 7a + 3$.

children.question:
The perimeter of a different regular polygon is $75b - 20$.

The length of one of its sides is $15b - 4$.

How many sides does this regular polygon have?

solutionDetails.working:
Let the number of sides in polygon $= n$

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
n \times (15b - 4)  &= 75b - 20 \\\\
n                   &= \dfrac {75b - 20} {15b - 4} \\\\
n                   &= \dfrac {5 \times 15b - 5 \times 4} {15b - 4} \\\\
n                   &= \dfrac {5 \times (15b - 4)} {15b - 4} \\\\
n                   &= \dfrac {5 \times (\cancel {15b - 4})} {\cancel {15b - 4}} \\\\
n                   &= 5
\end{aligned}
$

The regular polygon has 5 sides.

children.question:
The perimeter of a square is $4(c - 9)$.

Find the area of the square when $c = 15$.

solutionDetails.working:
Let the side of the sqaure $= a$

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
4 \times a         &= 4(c - 9) \\\\
4a                 &= 4 \times (c - 9) \\\\
a                  &= \dfrac {4 \times (c - 9)} {4} \\\\
a                  &= \dfrac {\cancel {4} \times (c - 9)} {\cancel {4}} \\\\
a                  &= c - 9 \\\\
a                  &= 15 - 9 \\\\
a                  &= 6 \ \text{cm}
\end{aligned}
$

Let's find the area of the square.

$
\begin{aligned}
\text {Area}            &= a \times a \\\\
                        &= 6 \times 6 \\\\
                        &= 36 \ \text{cm}^2
\end{aligned}
$
