<svg width="320" height="80" viewBox="0 0 320 80" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" role="img" aria-label="Number line">
  <line x1="20" y1="40" x2="300" y2="40" stroke="black" stroke-width="2"/>
  <line x1="20" y1="32" x2="20" y2="48" stroke="black" stroke-width="2"/>
            <text x="20" y="68" text-anchor="middle" font-size="14">0</text>
<line x1="76" y1="32" x2="76" y2="48" stroke="black" stroke-width="2"/>
            <text x="76" y="68" text-anchor="middle" font-size="14">1</text>
<line x1="132" y1="32" x2="132" y2="48" stroke="black" stroke-width="2"/>
            <text x="132" y="68" text-anchor="middle" font-size="14">2</text>
<line x1="188" y1="32" x2="188" y2="48" stroke="black" stroke-width="2"/>
            <text x="188" y="68" text-anchor="middle" font-size="14">3</text>
<line x1="244" y1="32" x2="244" y2="48" stroke="black" stroke-width="2"/>
            <text x="244" y="68" text-anchor="middle" font-size="14">4</text>
<line x1="300" y1="32" x2="300" y2="48" stroke="black" stroke-width="2"/>
            <text x="300" y="68" text-anchor="middle" font-size="14">5</text>
</svg>


Work out the sizes of angles $x, y$ and $z$.

Give reasons for your answers.

solutionDetails.working:
$ABD$ is an **isosceles** triangle. So,

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
x                                       &= 74 \degree \\\\
x  + y + 74                             &= 180 \\\\
74 + y + 74                             &= 180 \\\\
y + 148                                 &= 180 \\\\
y                                       &= 180 - 148 \\\\
y                                       &= 32 \degree
\end{aligned}
$

Let's use the value of $x$ and $y$ in triangle ABC.

$
\begin{aligned}
x + y + z + 28                              &= 180 \\\\
74 + 32 + z + 28                            &= 180 \\\\
z + 134                                     &= 180 \\\\
z                                           &= 180 - 134 \\\\
z                                           &= 46 \degree
\end{aligned}
$
solutionDetails.keepInMind: - When dividing by a fraction, multiply by the reciprocal.

questions.question:
Kaylee has some $1 \ \text{cm}$ cubes.

She makes a solid cube with side length $6 \ \text{cm}$ out of the cubes.


<svg width="260" height="160" viewBox="0 0 260 160" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" role="img" aria-label="Triangle">
  <polygon points="40,130 220,130 140,30" fill="none" stroke="black" stroke-width="2"/>
  <text x="125" y="150" font-size="14">base</text>
  <text x="145" y="25" font-size="14">A</text>
  <text x="28" y="135" font-size="14">B</text>
  <text x="225" y="135" font-size="14">C</text>
</svg>


Then she uses all these cubes to make some cubes with side length $2 \ \text{cm}$.

How many of these $2 \ \text{cm}$ cubes can Kaylee make?

solutionDetails.working:
$
\begin{aligned}
\text{Number of } 2 \text{ cm cubes}  &= \dfrac {\text{Volume of the } 6 \text{ cm cube}} {\text{Volume of the } 2 \text{ cm cube}} \\\\
                                      &= \dfrac {6 \times 6 \times 6} {2 \times 2 \times 2} \\\\
                                      &= \dfrac {2 \times 3 \times 2 \times 3 \times 2 \times 3} {2 \times 2 \times 2} \\\\
                                      &= \dfrac {\cancel{2} \times 3 \times \cancel{2} \times 3 \times \cancel{2} \times 3} {\cancel{2} \times \cancel{2} \times \cancel{2}} \\\\
                                      &= 3 \times 3 \times 3 \\\\
                                      &= 27
\end{aligned}
$
solutionDetails.keepInMind: - Check units and convert if needed.

            <text x="132" y="68" text-anchor="middle" font-size="14">2</text>

</svg>


Bag A: $6y + 1$ counters

Bag B: $4y + 7$ counters

The number of counters in each bag is the same.

Work out the value of $y$.

solutionDetails.working:
As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
6y + 1                                  &= 4y + 7 \\\\
6y - 4y                                 &= 7 - 1 \\\\
2y                                      &= 6 \\\\
y                                       &= \dfrac {6} {2} \\\\
y                                       &= \dfrac {2 \times 3} {2} \\\\
y                                       &= \dfrac {\cancel 2 \times 3} {\cancel 2} \\\\
y                                       &= 3
\end{aligned}
$
solutionDetails.keepInMind: - Line up digits carefully when adding or subtracting.

children.question:
Bag $C$ contains more counters than bag $D$.


<svg width="200" height="200" viewBox="0 0 200 200" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" role="img" aria-label="Pie chart slice">
  <circle cx="100" cy="100" r="70" fill="none" stroke="black" stroke-width="2"/>
  <path d="M100 100 L100 30 A70 70 0 0 1 165 120 Z" fill="none" stroke="black" stroke-width="2"/>
</svg>


Bag C: $4k$ counters

Bag D: $k + 12$ counters

What is the smallest possible value of $k$?

solutionDetails.working:
As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
4k                                  &> k + 12 \\\\
4k - k                              &> 12 \\\\
3k                                  &> 12 \\\\
k                                   &> \dfrac {12} {3} \\\\
k                                   &> \dfrac {3 \times 4} {3} \\\\
k                                   &> \dfrac {\cancel 3 \times 4} {\cancel 3} \\\\
k                                   &> 4
\end{aligned}
$

Smallest possible value of $k = 5$
solutionDetails.alternativeWorking:
**Alternative working 1**

As per the question,

$4k > k + 12$

We can easily infer the values by using trial and error. Let's find out the value of $k$ which satisfies the condition above.

| $k$ | Bag $C$ | Bag $D$ |  Bag $C$ > Bag $D$  |
|:-:|:-----------------:|:-----------------:|:---------------:|
|$1$| $4k = 4 \times 1 = 4$  |   $k + 12 = 1 + 12 = 13$   |       No        |
|$2$| $4k = 4 \times 2 = 8$  |   $k + 12 = 2 + 12 = 14$   |       No        |
|$3$| $4k = 4 \times 3 = 12$ |   $k + 12 = 3 + 12 = 15$   |       No        |
|$4$| $4k = 4 \times 4 = 16$ |   $k + 12 = 4 + 12 = 16$   |       No        |
|$5$| $4k = 4 \times 5 = 20$ |   $k + 12 = 5 + 12 = 17$   |       Yes       |


Smallest possible value of k $= 5$

questions.question:
One of the angles in an isosceles triangle is $30 \degree$. Which of these is a possible other angle in the triangle:

-  $90 \degree$
-  $80 \degree$
-  $150 \degree$
-  $60 \degree$
-  $75 \degree$

solutionDetails.working:
Let the other angle $= a$

As the triangle is an isosceles triangle, third angle $= a$

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
a + a + 30      &= 180 \\\\
2a + 30         &= 180 \\\\
2a              &= 180 - 30 \\\\
2a              &= 150 \\\\
a               &= \dfrac {150} {2} \\\\
a               &= \dfrac {75 \times 2} {2} \\\\
a               &= \dfrac {75 \times \cancel{2}}{\cancel{2}} \\\\
a               &= 75 \degree
\end{aligned}
$

Other angle $= 75 \degree$
solutionDetails.keepInMind: - Write the final answer with the correct unit.

questions.question:
One quarter of the pupils in a class are girls. The rest are boys. What is the ratio of girls to boys?

-  $1:1$
-  $1:2$
-  $1:3$
-  $1:4$
-  $1:5$

solutionDetails.working:
If $\dfrac {1} {4}$ of the pupils are girls. Then $1 - \dfrac {1} {4} = \dfrac {3} {4}$ will be boys. Using that, we get

$
\begin{array}{cccccccccccccc}
  & \text{girls}                                &:& \text{boys} \\\\
= & \dfrac{1} {4}                               &:& \dfrac {3} {4} \\\\
= & 1                                           &:& \dfrac {3 \times 4} {4} \\\\
= & 1                                           &:& \dfrac {3 \times \cancel 4} {\cancel 4} \\\\
= & 1                                           &:& 3
\end{array}
$
solutionDetails.keepInMind:
- Write the final answer with the correct unit.
- Show each step clearly; don’t do too much in one line.

questions.question:
I buy a pen and a pencil for $\pounds 1.10$. The pen costs $50 \ \text{p}$ more than the pencil. How much is the pen?

-  $50 \ \text{p}$
-  $60 \ \text{p}$
-  $70 \ \text{p}$
-  $80 \ \text{p}$
-  $90 \ \text{p}$

solutionDetails.working:
Let the price of pencil (in pence) $= a$

Price of pen (in pence) $= a + 50$

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
(a + a + 50)            &= 1.1 \times 100 \\\\
2a + 50                 &= 110 \\\\
2a                      &= 110 - 50 \\\\
a                       &= \dfrac {60} {2} \\\\
a                       &= \dfrac {30 \times 2} {2} \\\\
a                       &= \dfrac {30 \times \cancel{2}} {\cancel {2}} \\\\
a                       &= 30 \ \text{p}  \\\\
\text {Price of pen}    &= 50 + a \\\\
                        &= 50 + 30 \\\\
                        &= 80 \ \text{p}
\end{aligned}
$

children.question: In the next game he scored enough goals to increase his mean to $4$. How many goals did he score in the seventh game?

solutionDetails.working:
Let goals scored in the seventh game $= a$

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
\dfrac {3 + 4 + 2 + 0 + 1 + 8 + a} {7}  &= 4 \\\\
18 + a                                  &= 4 \times 7 \\\\
18 + a                                  &= 28 \\\\
a                                       &= 28 - 18 \\\\
a                                       &= 10
\end{aligned}
$

Goals scored in the seventh game $= 10$

children.question: I am making a scale model of The Eye-Full Tower, which is $120 \ \text{m}$ tall. If the scale is $1:50$, how long will the model be (in cm)?

solutionDetails.working:
Let length of the model $= a$

Using equivalent ratio,

$
\begin{aligned}
50 \ \text{m} : 1 \ \text{m}                    &= 120 \ \text{m} : a \ \text{m} \\\\
\dfrac {50} {1}                                 &= \dfrac {120} {a} \\\\
50 \times a                                     &= 120 \times 1 \\\\
a                                               &= \dfrac {120} {50} \ \text{m} \\\\
a                                               &= \dfrac {120 \times 100} {50} \ \text{cm} \\\\
a                                               &= \dfrac {120 \times 50 \times 2} {50} \\\\
a                                               &= \dfrac {120 \times \cancel {50} \times 2} {\cancel {50}} \\\\
a                                               &= 120 \times 2 \\\\
a                                               &= 240 \ \text{cm}
\end{aligned}
$

Length of the model $= 240 \ \text{cm}$
solutionDetails.alternativeWorking:
**Alternative working 1**

Using ratio,

$
\begin{array}{cccccccccccccc}
  & \text{tower}                                &:& \text{model} \\\\
= & 50 \ \text{m}                               &:& 1 \ \text{m} \\\\
= & 50 \ \text{m}                               &:& 1 \times 100 \ \text{cm} \\\\
= & 50                                          &:& 100 \\\\
= & 1                                           &:& \dfrac {100} {50} \\\\
= & 1 \times 120                                &:& \dfrac {100 \times 120} {50} \\\\
= & 120                                         &:& \dfrac {50 \times 2 \times 120} {50} \\\\
= & 120                                         &:& \dfrac {\cancel {50} \times 2 \times 120} {\cancel {50}} \\\\
= & 120                                         &:& 2 \times 120 \\\\
= & 120 \ \text{m}                              &:& 240 \ \text{cm}
\end{array}
$

Length of the model $= 240 \ \text{cm}$

children.question:
My friend Sanjay is making a scale model of the London Ear (a famous landmark in London).
The London Ear is $80 \ \text{m}$ tall and his model is $150 \ \text{cm}$ tall. What is the scale of the model, in its simplest form?

solutionDetails.working:
$
\begin{aligned}
\text{Scale}      &= \dfrac {\text{Length of the model}} {\text{Length of the tower}} \\\\
                  &= \dfrac {150 \ \text{cm}} {80 \ \text{m}} \\\\
                  &= \dfrac {150 \ \text{cm}} {80 \times 100 \ \text{cm}} \\\\
                  &= \dfrac {50 \times 3} {80 \times 50 \times 2} \\\\
                  &= \dfrac {\cancel {50} \times 3} {80 \times \cancel {50} \times 2} \\\\
                  &= \dfrac {3} {80 \times 2} \\\\
                  &= \dfrac {3} {160} \\\\
                  &= 3 : 160
\end{aligned}
$

children.question:
My other friend Minka was doing some gardening when she snapped a bamboo cane. The cane was $2.05 \ \text{m}$ long and is now
$156 \ \text{cm}$ long. What length of cane snapped off?

solutionDetails.working:
The original length is given in $\text{meters}$ while the new length measurement is given in $\text{cm}$.

Let's convert the original measurements into $\text{cm}$.

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
\text {Original length of cane}         &= 2.05 \ \text{m} \\\\
                                        &= 2.05 \times 100 \ \text{cm} \\\\
                                        &= 2.05 \times 100 \\\\
                                        &= 205 \ \text{cm} \\\\
\text {Legth of the cane snapped off}   &= \text {Original Length} - \text {New Length} \\\\
                                        &= 205 - 156 \\\\
                                        &= 49 \ \text{cm}
\end{aligned}
$

children.question:
In her garden, Ying-Ge is sowing some grass seed. The garden has an area of $158 \ \text{m}^2$ and each packet has enough seed for
$12 \ \text{m}^2$. How many packets does Ying-Ge need to buy?

solutionDetails.working:
As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
\text {Number of packets}   &= \dfrac {\text {Area of the garden}} {\text {Area per packet of seeds}} \\\\
                            &= \dfrac {158} {12} \\\\
                            &= \dfrac {12 \times 14} {12} \\\\
                            &= \dfrac {\cancel {12} \times 14} {\cancel {12}} \\\\
                            &= 14
\end{aligned}
$

On my wall I want to put some stickers of my favourite pop star Singing Steve.
The space I have available is $55 \ \text{cm}$ by $60 \ \text{cm}$ and the stickers are each $15 \ \text{cm}$ by $5 \ \text{cm}$.
What is the maximum number of stickers I can fit on the wall?

solutionDetails.working:
$
\begin{aligned}
\text{Number of stickers}  &= \dfrac {\text{Area of the wall}} {\text{Area of a sticker}} \\\\
                           &= \dfrac {55 \times 60} {15 \times 5} \\\\
                           &= \dfrac {5 \times 11 \times 15 \times 4} {15 \times 5} \\\\
                           &= \dfrac {\cancel {5} \times 11 \times \cancel {15} \times 4} {\cancel {15} \times \cancel {5} } \\\\
                           &= 11 \times 4 \\\\
                           &= 44
\end{aligned}
$

1 m = 100 cm
Area of square = side²

questions.question:
Two runners are having a race. Gary starts running from the start line at $10 \ \text{m/s}$.
Two seconds later Andy starts running from the start line at $12 \ \text{m/s}$.

children.question: How long after Gary starts running does Andy catch up with him?

solutionDetails.working:
Let the time taken by Gary to catch up (in seconds) $= t$

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
12 \times (t - 2)  &=  10 \times t \\\\
12t - 24           &=  10t \\\\
12t - 10t          &=  24 \\\\
2t                 &=  24 \\\\
t                  &=  \dfrac{24}{2} \\\\
t                  &=  \dfrac{12 \times 2}{2} \\\\
t                  &=  \dfrac{12 \times \cancel{2}}{\cancel{2}} \\\\
t                  &=  12 \text{ seconds}
\end{aligned}
$

Time taken $= 12 \text{ seconds}$
solutionDetails.keepInMind:
- Write the final answer with the correct unit.
- Check units and convert if needed.

children.question: What is the area of the square $ABCD$?

solutionDetails.working:
$
\begin{aligned}
\text{Side of the square}       &= \sqrt {(0 - 4) ^ 2 + (4 - 1) ^ 2} \\\\
                                &= \sqrt {(-4) ^ 2 + 3 ^ 2} \\\\
                                &= \sqrt {16 + 9} \\\\
                                &= \sqrt {25} \\\\
                                &= 5 \\\\
\text{Area of the square}       &= \text{(Side of the square)} ^ 2 \\\\
                                &= 5 ^ 2 \\\\
                                &= 25
\end{aligned}
$

questions.question:
Two of the angles in a triangle are $25 \degree$ and $107 \degree$. The third angle is:

-  $28 \degree$
-  $48 \degree$
-  $68 \degree$
-  $88 \degree$
-  $180 \degree$

solutionDetails.working:
Let the third angle $= a$

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
25 + 107 + a &= 180 \\\\
132 + a      &= 180 \\\\
a            &= 180 - 132 \\\\
a            &= 48 \degree
\end{aligned}
$

Third angle $= 48 \degree$
solutionDetails.keepInMind:
- Line up digits carefully when adding or subtracting.
- Use the correct order of operations (BIDMAS).

questions.question:
Bob counts the number of birds visiting his garden every day for a week. The counts were:

$17, 12, 8, 16, 2, 5, 10$

children.question: What was the mean score for the seven days?
What was the range?
A set of four numbers $5, 7, 12$ and $X$ have a mean of $10$. What is $X$?

solutionDetails.working:
As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
\dfrac {5 + 7 + 12 + X} {4}         &= 10 \\\\
5 + 7 + 12 + X                      &= 10 \times 4 \\\\
24 + X                              &= 40 \\\\
X                                   &= 40 - 24 \\\\
X                                   &= 16
\end{aligned}
$

Value of $X = 16$
solutionDetails.keepInMind: - Write the final answer with the correct unit.

children.question: According to Nigella, when making a birthday cake, the perfect ratio of flour to sugar is $140:200$. What is this ratio in its simplest form?
I am making a scale model of my yacht, which is $9 \ \text{m}$ long. If the scale is $1:30$, how long will the model yacht be (in cm)?

solutionDetails.working:
Let length of the model yacht $= a$

Using equivalent ratio,

$
\begin{aligned}
1 \ \text{m} : 30 \ \text{m}                    &= a \ \text{m} : 9 \ \text{m} \\\\
\dfrac{1} {30}                                  &= \dfrac {a} {9} \\\\
a \times 30                                     &= 9 \times 1 \\\\
a                                               &= \dfrac {9} {30} \ \text{m} \\\\
a                                               &= \dfrac {9 \times 100} {30} \ \text{cm} \\\\
a                                               &= \dfrac {3 \times 3 \times 10 \times 10} {3 \times 10} \\\\
a                                               &= \dfrac {3 \times \cancel 3 \times 10 \times \cancel {10}} {\cancel 3 \times \cancel {10}} \\\\
a                                               &= 30 \ \text{cm}
\end{aligned}
$

Length of the model yacht $= 30 \ \text{cm}$
solutionDetails.alternativeWorking:
**Alternative working 1**

Using ratio,

$
\begin{array}{cccccccccccccc}
  & \text{yacht}                  &:& \text{model} \\\\
= & 30 \ \text{m}                 &:& 1 \ \text{m} \\\\
= & 30 \ \text{m}                 &:& 1 \times 100 \ \text{cm} \\\\
= & 30 \ \text{m}                 &:& 100 \ \text{cm} \\\\
= & 1                             &:& \dfrac {100} {30} \\\\
= & 1 \times 9                    &:& \dfrac {100 \times 9} {30} \\\\
= & 9                             &:& \dfrac {100 \times 3 \times 3} {30} \\\\
= & 9                             &:& \dfrac {10 \cancel 0 \times 3 \times \cancel 3} {\cancel 3 \cancel 0} \\\\
= & 9                             &:& 10 \times 3 \\\\
= & 9 \ \text{m}                  &:& 30 \ \text{cm}
\end{array}
$

Length of the model yacht $= 30 \ \text{cm}$

When I lay a new patio in my back garden, I will need $290 \ \text{kg}$ of gravel. How many $12 \ \text{kg}$ bags do I need to buy?

solutionDetails.working:
As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
\text{Number of bags}               &= \dfrac {290} {12} \\\\
                                    &= \dfrac {145 \times 2} {6 \times 2} \\\\
                                    &= \dfrac {145 \times \cancel 2} {6 \times \cancel 2} \\\\
                                    &= \dfrac {145} {6} \\\\
                                    &= 24 \dfrac {1} {6} \\\\
                                    &= 25
\end{aligned}
$
solutionDetails.keepInMind: - Use the correct order of operations (BIDMAS).

questions.question:
On my wall I want to put some stickers of David Cameron. The space I have available is $80 \ \text{cm}$ by $45 \ \text{cm}$
and the stickers are each $5 \ \text{cm}$ by $10 \ \text{cm}$. What is the maximum number of stickers I can fit on the wall?

solutionDetails.working:
As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
\text{Number of stickers}  &= \dfrac {\text{Area of the wall}} {\text{Area of a sticker}} \\\\
                           &= \dfrac {80 \times 45} {10 \times 5} \\\\
                           &= \dfrac {8 \times 10 \times 5 \times 9} {10 \times 5} \\\\
                           &= \dfrac {8 \times \cancel {10} \times \cancel {5} \times 9} {\cancel {10} \times \cancel {5}} \\\\
                           &= 8 \times 9 \\\\
                           &= 72
\end{aligned}
$
solutionDetails.keepInMind:
- Show each step clearly; don’t do too much in one line.
- Line up digits carefully when adding or subtracting.

children.question: What is the area of the triangle formed by these three points?

solutionDetails.working:
$
\begin{aligned}
\text{Base of the triangle}     &= \sqrt {(-1 - 2) ^ 2 + (1 - 1) ^ 2} \\\\
                                &= \sqrt {(-3) ^ 2 + 0 ^ 2} \\\\
                                &= \sqrt {9 + 0} \\\\
                                &= \sqrt {9} \\\\
                                &= 3 \\\\
\text{Height of the triangle}   &= 2 - 1 \\\\
                                &= 1 \\\\
\text{Area of the square}       &= \dfrac {1} {2} \times \text{(Base of the triangle)} \times \text{(Height of the triangle)} \\\\
                                &= \dfrac {1} {2} \times 3 \times 1 \\\\
                                &= \dfrac {3} {2} \\\\
                                &= 1.5
\end{aligned}
$

questions.question:
What $5$-digit number has the following features:

If we put the numeral $1$ at the beginning, we get a number three times smaller than if we put the numeral $1$ at the end of the number?

In other words, if you think the answer is the number $34567$, then you want the number $134567$ to be one third of $345671$,
but it isn't, so what's the number?

solutionDetails.working:
Let the number $= a$

The number by putting $1$ at the beginning $= 100000 + a$

The number by putting $1$ at the end $= 1 + 10a$

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
1 + 10a                       &= 3 \times ( 100000 + a ) \\\\
1 + 10a                       &= 300000 + 3a \\\\
10a - 3a                      &= 300000 - 1 \\\\
7a                            &= 299999 \\\\
a                             &= \dfrac {299999} {7} \\\\
a                             &= \dfrac {42857 \times 7} {7} \\\\
a                             &= \dfrac {42857 \times \cancel 7} {\cancel 7} \\\\
a                             &= 42857
\end{aligned}
$

The required $5$-digit number $= 42857$.

Perimeter of square = 4 × side

children.question: $55 + \boxed{\phantom{55}} = 82$

solutionDetails.working:
Let the missing number $= a$

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
55 + a                              &= 82 \\\\
a                                   &= 82 - 55 \\\\
a                                   &= 27
\end{aligned}
$

Missing number $= 27$

children.question: $\boxed{\phantom{23}} - 23 = 45$

solutionDetails.working:
Let the missing number $= a$

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
a - 23                              &= 45 \\\\
a                                   &= 45 + 23 \\\\
a                                   &= 68
\end{aligned}
$

Missing number $= 68$

- Use the correct order of operations (BIDMAS).
- Show each step clearly; don’t do too much in one line.

children.question: $60 \div \boxed{\phantom{45}} = 12$

solutionDetails.working:
Let the missing number $= a$

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
60 \div a                           &= 12 \\\\
60                                  &= 12 \times a \\\\
a                                   &= \dfrac {60} {12}\\\\
a                                   &= \dfrac {5 \times 12} {12} \\\\
a                                   &= \dfrac {5 \times \cancel{12}} {\cancel{12}} \\\\
a                                   &= 5
\end{aligned}
$

Missing number $= 5$

$
\begin{aligned}
32 \times a                         &= 640 \\\\
a                                   &= \dfrac {640} {32} \\\\
a                                   &= \dfrac {20 \times 32} {32} \\\\
a                                   &= \dfrac {20 \times \cancel{32}} {\cancel{32}} \\\\
a                                   &= 20
\end{aligned}
$

Missing number $= 20$

Amar works for $45$ weeks each year.

How much is that per week?

$
\begin{aligned}
\text{Travelling cost per week}        &= \dfrac {\text{Total cost each year}} {\text{No. of weeks}} \\\\
                                              &= \dfrac {630} {45} \\\\
                                              &= \dfrac {14 \times 45} {45} \\\\
                                              &= \dfrac {14 \times \cancel{45}} {\cancel{45}} \\\\
                                              &= \pounds 14
\end{aligned}
$

At Redville Primary School, $16$ of the teachers travel to work by car, $6$ travel by bus and the other $3$ walk.

|  Car | Bus | Walk |
|:----:|:---:|:----:|
| $16$ | $6$ |  $3$ |

What *percentage* of the teachers travel by car?

solutionDetails.working:
$
\begin{aligned}
\text{Percentage of teachers}       &= \dfrac {\text{Teachers who travel by car}} {\text{Total teachers}} \times 100 \\\\
                                    &= \dfrac {16} {16 + 6 + 3} \times 100 \\\\
                                    &= \dfrac {16 \times 100} {25} \\\\
                                    &= \dfrac {16 \times 4 \times 25} {25} \\\\
                                    &= \dfrac {16 \times 4 \times \cancel{25}} {\cancel{25}} \\\\
                                    &= 16 \times 4 \\\\
                                    &= 64 \%
\end{aligned}
$
solutionDetails.keepInMind:
- Use the correct order of operations (BIDMAS).
- Show each step clearly; don’t do too much in one line.

children.question:
Jo and Aisha bought identical jeans from a market stall.

Jo got $10 \%$ discount of the full price.

Aisha got $15 \%$ discount of the full price. Jo paid $\pounds 1.20$ more than Aisha.

What was the full price of the jeans?

solutionDetails.working:
Let the full price of the jeans $= p$

Jo got $10 \%$ discount and Aisha got $15 \%$ discount. So Jo paid $15 - 10 = 5 \%$ more of the full price.

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
5 \% \ \text{of} \ p        &= 1.20 \\\\
\dfrac {5} {100} \times p   &= 1.20 \\\\
p                           &= \dfrac {1.20 \times 100} {5} \\\\
p                           &= \dfrac {1.20 \times 20 \times 5} {5} \\\\
p                           &= \dfrac {1.20 \times 20 \times \cancel{5}} {\cancel{5}} \\\\
p                           &= 1.20 \times 20 \\\\
p                           &= \pounds 24
\end{aligned}
$

Full price of the jeans $= \pounds 24$
solutionDetails.alternativeWorking:
**Alternative working 1**


Let the full price of the jeans $= p$

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
(p - 10 \% \ \text{of} \ p)  - (p - 15 \% \ \text{of} \ p)  &= 1.20 \\\\
p - 10 \% \ \text{of} \ p  - p + 15 \% \ \text{of} \ p      &= 1.20 \\\\
15 \% \ \text{of} \ p - 10 \% \ \text{of} \ p               &= 1.20 \\\\
5 \% \ \text{of} \ p                                        &= 1.20 \\\\
\dfrac {5} {100} \times p                                   &= 1.20 \\\\
p                                                           &= \dfrac {1.20 \times 100} {5} \\\\
p                                                           &= \dfrac {1.20 \times 20 \times 5} {5} \\\\
p                                                           &= \dfrac {1.20 \times 20 \times \cancel{5}} {\cancel{5}} \\\\
p                                                           &= 1.20 \times 20 \\\\
p                                                           &= \pounds 24
\end{aligned}
$

Full price of the jeans $= \pounds 24$
solutionDetails.keepInMind: - When dividing by a fraction, multiply by the reciprocal.

children.question:
Chris runs round a track at a speed of $6 \ \text{km/hour}$.

Dave runs round the same track at a speed of $9 \ \text{km/hour}$.

When Chris has run $18$ laps, how many laps has Dave run?

solutionDetails.working:
$
\begin{aligned}
\text {Ratio of their speed}            &= \dfrac {9} {6} \\\\
                                        &= \dfrac {3 \times 3} {3 \times 2} \\\\
                                        &= \dfrac {\cancel{3} \times 3} {\cancel{3} \times 2} \\\\
                                        &= \dfrac {3} {2} \\\\
\text {Laps ran by Dave}                &= \dfrac {3} {2} \ \text {of} \ 18 \\\\
                                        &= \dfrac {3} {2} \times 18 \\\\
                                        &= \dfrac {3 \times 18} {2} \\\\
                                        &= \dfrac {3 \times 9 \times 2} {2} \\\\
                                        &= \dfrac {3 \times 9 \times \cancel{2}} {\cancel{2}} \\\\
                                        &= 3 \times 9 \\\\
                                        &= 27
\end{aligned}
$

children.question: Two numbers have a difference of $3$ and a sum of $27$. What are the two numbers?

solutionDetails.working:
Let the first number $= a$

Second number $= a + 3$

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
a + (a + 3)                 &= 27 \\\\
2a + 3                      &= 27 \\\\
2a                          &= 27 - 3 \\\\
a                           &= \dfrac {24} {2} \\\\
a                           &= \dfrac {2 \times 12} {2} \\\\
a                           &= \dfrac {\cancel 2 \times 12} {\cancel 2} \\\\
a                           &= 12
\end{aligned}
$

$
\begin{aligned}
\text{First number} &= 12 \\\\
\text{Second number} &= 12 + 3 \\\\
                         &= 15
\end{aligned}
$

questions.question:
The total length of the edges of a cube is $240 \ \text{cm}$. What is the length of one edge?


<svg width="260" height="160" viewBox="0 0 260 160" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" role="img" aria-label="Bar chart">
  <line x1="30" y1="130" x2="240" y2="130" stroke="black" stroke-width="2"/>
  <line x1="30" y1="130" x2="30" y2="20" stroke="black" stroke-width="2"/>
  <rect x="55" y="70" width="25" height="60" fill="none" stroke="black" stroke-width="2"/>
  <rect x="100" y="50" width="25" height="80" fill="none" stroke="black" stroke-width="2"/>
  <rect x="145" y="90" width="25" height="40" fill="none" stroke="black" stroke-width="2"/>
  <rect x="190" y="35" width="25" height="95" fill="none" stroke="black" stroke-width="2"/>
</svg>

solutionDetails.working:
Total number of edges in a cube $= 12$

Let the edge of the cube $= a$

$
\begin{aligned}
12 \times a &= 240 \\\\
a           &= \dfrac {240} {12} \\\\
a           &= \dfrac {12 \times 20} {12} \\\\
a           &= \dfrac { \cancel {12} \times 20} {\cancel {12}} \\\\
a           &= 20 \ \text{cm}
\end{aligned}
$

questions.question:
Here is some information about three different squares:

The *area* of Vikram's square is $64 \ \text{cm}^2$.

The *length of a side* of Kim's square is $64 \ \text{cm}$.

The *perimeter* of Ali's square is $64 \ \text{cm}$.

children.question: Who has the largest square?

solutionDetails.working:
As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
\text {Area of Vikram's square}             &= 64 \ \text{cm}^2 \\\\
\text {Area of Kim's square}                &= 64 \times 64 \\\\
                                            &= 4096 \ \text{cm}^2 \\\\
\text {Let the side of the Ali's square}    &= a \\\\
4 \times a                                  &= 64 \\\\
a                                           &= \dfrac {64} {4} \\\\
a                                           &= \dfrac {4 \times 16} {4} \\\\
a                                           &= \dfrac {\cancel {4} \times 16} {\cancel {4}} \\\\
a                                           &= 16 \ \text{cm} \\\\
\text {Area of Ali's square}                &= a \times a \\\\
                                            &= 16 \times 16 \\\\
                                            &= 256 \ \text{cm}^2
\end{aligned}
$

Ali has the largest square.

children.question: Who has the smallest square?

solutionDetails.working:
As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
\text {Area of Vikram's square}             &= 64 \ \text{cm}^2 \\\\
\text {Area of Kim's square}                &= 64 \times 64 \\\\
                                            &= 4096 \ \text{cm}^2 \\\\
\text {Let the side of the Ali's square}    &= a \\\\
4 \times a                                  &= 64 \\\\
a                                           &= \dfrac {64} {4} \\\\
a                                           &= \dfrac {4 \times 16} {4} \\\\
a                                           &= \dfrac {\cancel {4} \times 16} {\cancel {4}} \\\\
a                                           &= 16 \ \text{cm} \\\\
\text {Area of Ali's square}                &= a \times a \\\\
                                            &= 16 \times 16 \\\\
                                            &= 256 \ \text{cm}^2
\end{aligned}
$

Vikram has the smallest square.

Area of square = side²
Perimeter of square = 4 × side

Lollipops cost $12 \ \text{p}$ each, or a pack of $3$ costs $30 \ \text{p}$.

I have $\pounds 2$ to spend.

What is the maximum number of lollipops I can buy?

solutionDetails.working:
Lets find out how many packs of $3$ lollipops can be bought, then we find how many individual lollipops can be bought with the remaining money.

$
\begin{aligned}
\text {Number of packs}             &= \dfrac {\pounds 2} {30 \ \text{p}} \\\\
                                    &= \dfrac {200 \ \text{p}} {30 \ \text{p}} \\\\
                                    &= 6 \ \text {remainder } 20 \\\\
                                    &\approx 6 \\\\
\text {Money left}                  &= 200 - 6 \times 30 \\\\
                                    &= 200 - 180 \\\\
                                    &= 20 \ \text{p} \\\\
\text {Extra lollipops we can buy}  &= \dfrac {20} {12} \\\\
                                    &= 1 \ \text {remainder} \ 8 \\\\
                                    &\approx 1 \\\\
\text {Total lollipops}             &= 6 \times 3 + 1 \\\\
                                    &= 18 + 1 \\\\
                                    &= 19
\end{aligned}
$

children.question:
Every $100 \ \text{g}$ of brown bread contains $6 \ \text{g}$ of fibre.

A small loaf weighs $400 \ \text{g}$ and has $10$ equal slices.

How much fibre is there in one slice?

solutionDetails.working:
Using ratio,

$
\begin{array}{cccccccccccccc}
  & \text{bread}                  &:& \text{fibre} \\\\
= & 100 \ \text{g}                &:& 6 \ \text{g} \\\\
= & 100 \times 4 \ \text{g}       &:& 6 \times 4 \ \text{g} \\\\
= & 400 \ \text{g}                &:& 24 \ \text{g} \\\\
= & 10 \ \text{slice}             &:& 24 \ \text{g} \\\\
= & 1 \ \text{slice}              &:& \dfrac {24} {10} \ \text{g} \\\\
= & 1 \ \text{slice}              &:& 2.4 \ \text{g}
\end{array}
$

Fibre in one slice $= 2.4 \ \text{g}$

children.question:
On the cards below, each club $\spadesuit$ has the same value and
each spade $\spadesuit$ has the same value (but a different value to each club).

The number on each card is the total value of the symbols on that card.

Find the value of one club.


<svg width="240" height="140" viewBox="0 0 240 140" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" role="img" aria-label="Table">
  <rect x="40" y="30" width="160" height="80" fill="none" stroke="black" stroke-width="2"/>
  <line x1="40" y1="60" x2="200" y2="60" stroke="black" stroke-width="2"/>
  <line x1="40" y1="85" x2="200" y2="85" stroke="black" stroke-width="2"/>
  <line x1="95" y1="30" x2="95" y2="110" stroke="black" stroke-width="2"/>
  <line x1="150" y1="30" x2="150" y2="110" stroke="black" stroke-width="2"/>
</svg>

solutionDetails.working:
Let the value of spade $= s$

Value of club $= c$

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
2c + 2s             &= 20 \\\\
2c + 3s             &= 27
\end{aligned}
$

We have got $2$ variables and we have $2$ equations to solve them. Let's eliminate to reduce it to just one variable.

Subtract the first equation from the second to reduce it to one variable.

$
\begin{aligned}
2c + 3s - (2c + 2s)                 &= 27 - 20 \\\\
2c + 3s - 2c - 2s                   &= 7 \\\\
s                                   &= 7
\end{aligned}
$

Substituting the value of $s$ in the first equation,

$
\begin{aligned}
2c + 2s          &= 20 \\\\
2c + 2 \times 7  &= 20 \\\\
2c + 14          &= 20 \\\\
2c               &= 20 - 14 \\\\
2c               &= 6 \\\\
c                &= \dfrac {6} {2} \\\\
c                &= 3
\end{aligned}
$

Value of club $= 3$

questions.question:
Claire is two years older than her brother and five years younger than her sister.
The total of their ages is $87$ years.

How old is Claire?

solutionDetails.working:
Let Claire's age $= a$

Her brother's age $= a - 2$

Her sister's age $= a + 5$

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
a + a - 2 + a + 5   &= 87 \\\\
3a + 3              &= 87 \\\\
3a                  &= 87 - 3 \\\\
3a                  &= 84 \\\\
a                   &= \dfrac {84} {3} \\\\
a                   &= \dfrac {28 \times 3} {3} \\\\
a                   &= \dfrac {28 \times \cancel {3}} {\cancel {3}} \\\\
a                   &= 28 \ \text {years}
\end{aligned}
$

Claire's age $= 28 \ \text {years}$

children.question:
The area of a right angled triangle is $32 \ \text{cm}^{2}$.

The lengths, in $\text{cm}$, of the two shorter sides are both different square numbers bigger than $1$.

What are the lengths of the two shorter sides?

solutionDetails.working:
Let the height of the triangle $= h$

Let the base of the triangle $= b$

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
\dfrac {1} {2} \times b \times h    &= 32 \\\\
\dfrac {b \times h} {2}             &= 32 \\\\
b \times h                          &= 32 \times 2 \\\\
b \times h                          &= 64
\end{aligned}
$

Factors of $64 = 1, 2, 4, 8, 16, 32, 64$

Factor pairs of $64$ that are both different square numbers $ = 4, 16$

Length of the two shorter sides are $4 \ \text{cm}$ and $16 \ \text{cm}$.

children.question: Seven *consecutive* whole numbers add up to $7357$.  What is the largest of the seven numbers?

solutionDetails.working:
Let the seven consecutive whole numbers $= a, a+1, a+2, a+3, a+4, a+5, a+6$

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
a + a + 1 + a + 2 + a + 3 + a + 4 + a + 5 + a + 6   &= 7357 \\\\
7a + 21                                             &= 7357 \\\\
7a                                                  &= 7357 - 21 \\\\
7a                                                  &= 7336 \\\\
a                                                   &= \dfrac {7336} {7} \\\\
a                                                   &= \dfrac {7 \times 1048} {7} \\\\
a                                                   &= \dfrac {\cancel 7 \times 1048} {\cancel 7} \\\\
a                                                   &= 1048
\end{aligned}
$

$
\begin{aligned}
\text{The largest whole number}     &= 1048 + 6 \\\\
                                    &= 1054
\end{aligned}
$

children.question: When three *consecutive* whole numbers are multiplied together, the answer is $990$. What are the three numbers?

solutionDetails.working:
Let the three consecutive whole numbers $= a, a + 1, a+2$

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
a \times (a + 1) \times (a + 2)         &= 990
\end{aligned}
$

We can easily infer the values by using trial and error.


| $a$ | Product $(a)(a+1)(a+2)$       | Equals $990$? |
|:-------------:|:------------------------------:|:--------------:|
| $a = 8$           | $8 \times 9 \times 10 = 720$   | No             |
| $a = 9$           | $9 \times 10 \times 11 = 990$  | Yes          |
| $a = 10$          | $10 \times 11 \times 12 = 1320$| No             |

Numbers $= 9, 10, 11$.

children.question: How many Tinkles make one Clink?

solutionDetails.working:
From the Tinkles column, the sum given in the table is less than $15$, so there is a carry of $15 - 3 = 12$ Tinkles.

From the Clinks column, the sum given in the table is more than $6$, so there is a carry of $8 - 6 = 2$ Clinks.

This means that $12$ Tinkles make $2$ Clinks.

$
\begin{aligned}
\text{Total Clinks}             &= 2 + 2 + 1 + 1 \\\\
                                &= 6 \\\\
\text{Total Tinkles}            &= 5 + 4 + 3 + 3 \\\\
                                &= 15 \\\\
\text{Carry over Tinkles}        &= 15 - 3 \\\\
                                &= 12 \\\\
\text{Carry over Clinks}         &= 8 - 6 \\\\
                                &= 2 \\\\
\text{Tinkles per Clink}      &= \dfrac {12} {2} \\\\
                                        &= 6
\end{aligned}
$

Answer: $6$ Tinkles make $1$ Clink
solutionDetails.keepInMind:
- Check units and convert if needed.
- Line up digits carefully when adding or subtracting.

children.question: $\boxed{\phantom{23}} \times 0.25 = 1$

solutionDetails.working:
Let the missing number $= a$

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
a \times 0.25                   &= 1 \\\\
a                               &= \dfrac {1} {0.25} \\\\
a                               &= \dfrac {100} {25} \\\\
a                               &= \dfrac {25 \times 4} {25} \\\\
a                               &= \dfrac {\cancel {25} \times 4} {\cancel {25}} \\\\
a                               &= 4
\end{aligned}
$

Missing number $= 4$

children.question: $64 \div 8 = 32 \div \boxed{\phantom{23}}$

solutionDetails.working:
Let the missing number $= a$

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
64 \div 8                       &= 32 \div a \\\\
\dfrac {64} {8}                 &= \dfrac {32} {a} \\\\
a                               &= 32 \times \dfrac {8} {64} \\\\
a                               &= \dfrac {32 \times 8} {64} \\\\
a                               &= \dfrac {32 \times 2 \times 4} {32 \times 2} \\\\
a                               &= \dfrac {\cancel {32} \times \cancel 2 \times 4} {\cancel {32} \times \cancel 2} \\\\
a                               &= 4
\end{aligned}
$

Missing number $= 4$

\end{aligned}
$

questions.question:
My four pet monkeys collected a pile of $60$ peanuts.

Monkey $A$ woke in the night and ate half of them,

then Monkey $B$ woke and ate one third of what was left,

then Monkey $C$ woke and ate one quarter of the rest

and finally Monkey $D$ woke and ate one fifth of what remainder.

children.question: How many peanuts did Monkey $D$ eat?

solutionDetails.working:
As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
\text{Peanuts eaten by Monkey A}        &= \dfrac {1} {2} \times 60 \\\\
                                        &= \dfrac {60} {2} \\\\
                                        &= \dfrac {30 \times 2} {2} \\\\
                                        &= \dfrac {30 \times \cancel 2} {\cancel 2} \\\\
                                        &= 30 \\\\
\text{Peanuts eaten by Monkey B}          &= \dfrac {1} {3} \times (60 - 30) \\\\
                                        &= \dfrac {30} {3} \\\\
                                        &= \dfrac {10 \times 3} {3} \\\\
                                        &= \dfrac {10 \times \cancel 3} {\cancel 3} \\\\
                                        &= 10 \\\\
\text{Peanuts eaten by Monkey C}          &= \dfrac {1} {4} \times (60 - 30 - 10) \\\\
                                        &= \dfrac {20} {4} \\\\
                                        &= \dfrac {5 \times 4} {4} \\\\
                                        &= \dfrac {5 \times \cancel 4} {\cancel 4} \\\\
                                        &= 5 \\\\
\text{Peanuts eaten by Monkey D}          &= \dfrac {1} {5} \times (60 - 30 - 10 - 5) \\\\
                                        &= \dfrac {15} {5} \\\\
                                        &= \dfrac {3 \times 5} {5} \\\\
                                        &= \dfrac {3 \times \cancel 5} {\cancel 5} \\\\
                                        &= 3
\end{aligned}
$
solutionDetails.alternativeWorking:
**Alternative working 1**


As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
\text{Peanuts left after Monkey A}      &= \dfrac {1} {2} \times 60 \\\\
\text{Peanuts left after Monkey B}      &= \dfrac {2} {3} \times \dfrac {1} {2} \times 60 \\\\
\text{Peanuts left after Monkey C}      &= \dfrac {3} {4} \times \dfrac {2} {3} \times \dfrac {1} {2} \times 60 \\\\
\text{Peanuts eaten by Monkey D}        &= \dfrac {1} {5} \times \dfrac {3} {4} \times \dfrac {2} {3} \times \dfrac {1} {2} \times 60 \\\\
                                        &= \dfrac {3 \times 2 \times 60} {5 \times 4 \times 3 \times 2} \\\\
                                        &= \dfrac {3 \times 2 \times 5 \times 4 \times 3} {5 \times 4 \times 3 \times 2} \\\\
                                        &= \dfrac {3 \times \cancel 2 \times \cancel 5 \times \cancel 4 \times \cancel 3} {\cancel 5 \times \cancel 4 \times \cancel 3 \times \cancel 2} \\\\
                                        &= 3
\end{aligned}
$

questions.question:
Last week George spent $12 \ \text{hours}$ playing on his Xbox.

He spent the same length of time on it each weekday and twice as long on it each day at the weekend.

How long (in hours and minutes) did he send on his Xbox on Saturday?

solutionDetails.working:
Let the time spent playing each weekday $= a$

Time spent playing on weekend $= 2a$

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
5 \times a + 2 \times 2a         &= 12  \\\\
5a + 4a                          &= 12 \\\\
9a                               &= 12 \\\\
a                                &= \dfrac {12} {9} \\\\
a                                &= \dfrac {3 \times 4} {3 \times 3} \\\\
a                                &= \dfrac {\cancel{3} \times 4} {\cancel{3} \times 3} \\\\
a                                &= \dfrac {4} {3} \ \text {hours}
\end{aligned}
$

$
\begin{aligned}
\text{Time spent on saturday}    &= 2a  \\\\
                                 &= 2 \times \dfrac {4} {3} \\\\
                                 &= \dfrac {8} {3} \\\\
                                 &= 2 \dfrac {2} {3} \ \text {hours} \\\\
                                 &= 2 \ \text {hours } 40 \ \text {minutes}
\end{aligned}
$
solutionDetails.keepInMind:
- Write the final answer with the correct unit.
- Use the correct order of operations (BIDMAS).

children.question:
Chan now empties the jug of water by pouring equal amounts into six identical empty beakers.
One of the beakers is shown in the diagram.

Draw a line on the beaker to indicate the level of water in it.

solutionDetails.working:
$
\begin{aligned}
\text {Water in each beaker}                      &= \dfrac {\text{total water}} {\text{total beakers}} \\\\
                                                  &= \dfrac {1800} {6} \\\\
                                                  &= 300 \text {ml} \\\\
\text {Water in one division of beaker}           &= \dfrac {\text{total capacity}} {\text{number of divisions}} \\\\
                                                  &= \dfrac {400} {8} \\\\
                                                  &= \dfrac {8 \times 50} {8} \\\\
                                                  &= \dfrac {\cancel{8} \times 50} {\cancel{8}} \\\\
                                                  &= 50 \\\\
\text{Number of divisions containing 300ml water} &= \dfrac {300} {50} \\\\
                                                  &= \dfrac {50 \times 6} {50} \\\\
                                                  &= \dfrac {\cancel{50} \times 6} {50} \\\\
                                                  &= 6
\end{aligned}
$

6th division is to be marked.
solutionDetails.keepInMind: - Show each step clearly; don’t do too much in one line.

children.question: $20 \%$ of a number is $3.2$. What is the number?

solutionDetails.working:
Let the number $=a$

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
20 \% \ \text{of} \ a           &= 3.2 \\\\
\dfrac {20} {100} \times a      &= \dfrac {32} {10} \\\\
a                               &= \dfrac {32} {10} \times \dfrac {100} {20} \\\\
a                               &= \dfrac {32 \times 100} {10 \times 20} \\\\
a                               &= \dfrac {16 \times 2 \times 20 \times 5} {2 \times 5 \times 20} \\\\
a                               &= \dfrac {16 \times \cancel 2 \times \cancel {20} \times \cancel 5} {\cancel 2 \times \cancel 5 \times \cancel {20}} \\\\
a                               &= 16
\end{aligned}
$
solutionDetails.keepInMind:
- When dividing by a fraction, multiply by the reciprocal.
- Use the correct order of operations (BIDMAS).

questions.question: $40 \%$ of the children on a school trip are boys and there are $72$ girls. How many children are on the trip?

solutionDetails.working:
Let the total number of children $= a$

If $40 \%$ of the children are boys, then the girls are $100 - 40 = 60 \%$.


As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
60 \%  \text{ of }  a         &= 72 \\\\
\dfrac {60} {100} \times a          &= 72 \\\\
a                                   &= 72 \times \dfrac {100} {60} \\\\
a                                   &= \dfrac {72 \times 100} {60} \\\\
a                                   &= \dfrac {12 \times 6 \times 100} {6 \times 10} \\\\
a                                   &= \dfrac {12 \times \cancel 6 \times 10 \cancel 0} {\cancel 6 \times 1 \cancel 0} \\\\
a                                   &= 12 \times 10 \\\\
a                                   &= 120
\end{aligned}
$

Number of children $= 120$

What number should Luke start with to get an answer of $24?$

solutionDetails.working:
Let the number $= a$

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
a \times 2 - 5          &= 24 \\\\
2a                      &= 24 + 5 \\\\
a                       &= \dfrac {29} {2} \\\\
a                       &= 14.5
\end{aligned}
$

Answer $= 14.5$.
solutionDetails.keepInMind:
- Use the correct order of operations (BIDMAS).
- Check units and convert if needed.

children.question: How long (in hours and minutes) does each person take?

solutionDetails.working:
$
\begin{aligned}
\text{Time taken by Rio}   &=  \dfrac{200}{80} \\\\
                           &=  \dfrac{4 \times 5 \times 10}{4 \times 2 \times 10} \\\\
                           &=  \dfrac{\cancel{4} \times 5 \times \cancel{10}}{\cancel{4} \times 2 \times \cancel{10}} \\\\
                           &=  \dfrac{5}{2} \text{ hours} \\\\
                           &=  2\dfrac{1}{2} \text{ hours} \\\\
                           &=  2 \text{ hours } 30 \text{ minutes} \\\\
\text{Time taken by Harry} &=  \dfrac{150 + 150}{100} \\\\
                           &=  \dfrac{300}{100} \\\\
                           &=  \dfrac{3 \times 100}{100} \\\\
                           &=  \dfrac{3 \times \cancel{100}}{\cancel{100}} \\\\
                           &=  3 \text{ hours} \\\\
\text{Time taken by Fahad} &=  \dfrac{200}{60} \\\\
                           &=  \dfrac{2 \times 2 \times 5 \times 10}{3 \times 2 \times 10} \\\\
                           &=  \dfrac{2 \times \cancel{2} \times 5 \times \cancel{10}}{3 \times \cancel{2} \times \cancel{10}} \\\\
                           &=  \dfrac{2 \times 5}{3} \\\\
                           &=  \dfrac{10}{3} \\\\
                           &=  3\dfrac{1}{3} \text{ hours} \\\\
                           &=  3 \text{ hours } 20 \text{ minutes}
\end{aligned}
$
solutionDetails.keepInMind:
- Show each step clearly; don’t do too much in one line.
- When dividing by a fraction, multiply by the reciprocal.

The total surface are of a cube is $96 \ \text{cm}^2$.

children.question: What is the area of one face of the cube?

solutionDetails.working:
Let the edge of the cube $= a$

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
6 \times a \times a                       &= 96 \\\\
6 \times a^2                              &= 96 \\\\
a^2                                       &= \dfrac {96} {6} \\\\
a^2                                       &= \dfrac {6 \times 16} {6} \\\\
a^2                                       &= \dfrac {\cancel {6} \times 16} {\cancel {6}} \\\\
a^2                                       &= 16 \\\\
a                                         &= \sqrt {16} \\\\
a                                         &= 4 \ \text{cm}
\end{aligned}
$

Let's find the area of one face of the cube.

$
\begin{aligned}
\text {Area of once face}       &= a \times a \\\\
                                &= 4 \times 4 \\\\
                                &= 16 \ \text{cm}^2
\end{aligned}
$

children.question: What is the length of one edge of the cube?

As per the question,

$

a^2                                       &= \dfrac {96} {6} \\\\
a^2                                       &= \dfrac {6 \times 16} {6} \\\\
a^2                                       &= \dfrac {\cancel {6} \times 16} {\cancel {6}} \\\\
a^2                                       &= 16 \\\\
a                                         &= \sqrt {16} \\\\
a                                         &= 4 \ \text{cm}
\end{aligned}
$

Length of one edge of cube $= 4 \ \text{cm}$

children.question:
Yusuf has $6$ equilateral triangles, each with a perimeter of $12 \ \text{cm}$.

He fits them together to make a regular hexagon.

What is the hexagon's perimeter?

solutionDetails.working:
*Not completed yet.:: Add two diagram a small equilateral triangle and a hexagon which is made by adding 6 small ones.
Show each side of hexagon is equal to triangle.*

Let the side of equilateral triangle $= a$

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
3 \times a          &= 12 \\\\
a                   &= \dfrac {12} {3} \\\\
a                   &= \dfrac {3 \times 4} {3} \\\\
a                   &= \dfrac {\cancel {3} \times 4} {\cancel {3}} \\\\
a                   &= 4 \ \text{cm}
\end{aligned}
$

As per the diagram,

$
\begin{aligned}
\text {Side of hexagon}                 &= a \\\\
                                        &= 4 \ \text{cm}\\\\
\text {Perimeter of hexagon}            &= 6 \times a \\\\
                                        &= 24 \ \text{cm}
\end{aligned}
$

children.question:
Shreya has $4$ equilateral triangles, each with a perimeter of $12 \ \text{cm}$.

She fits them together to make a  larger equilateral triangle.

What is the perimeter of the larger equilateral triangle?

solutionDetails.working:
*Not completed yet.:: Add two diagram a small equilateral triangle and a larger equilateral triangle which is made by adding 4 small ones.
Show each side of larger triangle is $2 \times \ \text {side of smaller triangle}$.*

Let the side of smaller equilateral triangle $= a$

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
3 \times a          &= 12 \\\\
a                   &= \dfrac {12} {3} \\\\
a                   &= \dfrac {3 \times 4} {3} \\\\
a                   &= \dfrac {\cancel {3} \times 4} {\cancel {3}} \\\\
a                   &= 4 \ \text{cm}
\end{aligned}
$

As per the diagram,

$
\begin{aligned}
\text {Side of larger triangle}         &= 2 \times a \\\\
                                        &= 2 \times 4 \\\\
                                        &= 8 \ \text{cm}\\\\
\text {Perimeter of larger triangle}    &= 3 \times 8 \\\\
                                        &= 24 \ \text{cm}
\end{aligned}
$

questions.question:
A litre of water wieghs $1 \ \text{kg}$ and a litre of ice weighs $900 \ \text{g}$.

How many more grams will $6 \ \text{litres}$ of water weigh compared to $5 \ \text{litres}$ of ice?

solutionDetails.working:
$
\begin{aligned}
\text{Weight of 6 litres of water}    &= 6 \times 1 \\\\
                                      &= 6 \ \text{kg} \\\\
                                      &= 6 \times 1000 \ \text{g} \\\\
                                      &= 6000 \ \text{g} \\\\
\text{Weight of 5 litres of ice}      &= 5 \times 900 \\\\
                                      &= 4500 \ \text{g} \\\\
\text{Difference}                     &= 6000 - 4500 \\\\
                                      &= 1500 \ \text{g}
\end{aligned}
$

questions.question:
Jada picks one of these cards at random.

$
\large {
\boxed {1} \quad
\boxed {2} \quad
\boxed {3} \quad
\boxed {4} \quad
\boxed {5} \quad
\boxed {6} \quad
\boxed {7} \quad
\boxed {8} \quad
\boxed {9}
}
$

Here are some possible outcomes:

- The number on the card will be a factor of $24$.
- The number on the card will be a multiple of $2$.
- The number on the card will be a multiple of $3$.
- The number on the card will be a multiple of $5$.
- The number on the card will be a square number.

children.question: Which of these outcomes $(A, B, C, D, E)$ is most likely to happen?
children.answer: The number on the card will be a factor of $24$.

solutionDetails.working:
$
\begin{aligned}
\text{factors of 24}            &= 1, 2, 3,4, 6, 8 \\\\
\text{P(factors of 24)}         &= \dfrac {6} {9} \\\\
                                &= \dfrac {3 \times 2} {3 \times 3} \\\\
                                &= \dfrac {2 \times \cancel{3}} {\cancel{3} \times 3} \\\\
                                &= \dfrac {2} {3} \\\\
\text{multiples of 2}           &= 2, 4, 6, 8 \\\\
\text{P(multiples of 2)}        &= \dfrac {4} {9} \\\\
\text{multiples of 3}           &= 3, 6, 9 \\\\
\text{P(multiples of 3)}        &= \dfrac {3} {9} \\\\
                                &= \dfrac {3} {3 \times 3} \\\\
                                &= \dfrac {\cancel{3}} {\cancel{3} \times 3} \\\\
                                &= \dfrac {1} {3}  \\\\
\text{multiples of 5}           &= 5 \\\\
\text{P(multiples of 5)}        &= \dfrac {1} {9} \\\\
\text{square numbers}           &= 4, 9  \\\\
\text{P(square numbers)}        &= \dfrac {2} {9}
\end{aligned}
$

Highest probability $= \dfrac {2} {3}$ for factors of $24$

children.question: How many grey tiles will be there in Shape Number $20?$

solutionDetails.working:
The number of grey tiles is calculated by adding $1$ to the previous number of grey tiles.

This is an arithmetic sequence too and the difference between the consecutive patterns of the sequence is constant.

The next grey tiles is calculated by adding multiple of $1$ grey tiles to the first pattern and the number of times it is added is based on the position in the sequence.

$
\begin{aligned}
\text{Number of grey tiles}   &= 3 + (20 - 1) \times 1 \\\\
                              &= 3 + 19 \times 1 \\\\
                              &= 3 + 19 \\\\
                              &= 22
\end{aligned}
$
solutionDetails.keepInMind:
- Line up digits carefully when adding or subtracting.
- Show each step clearly; don’t do too much in one line.

children.question: How many whilte tiles will there be in Shape Number $36?$

solutionDetails.working:
The number of white tiles is calculated by adding $2$ to the previous number of white tiles.

This is an arithmetic sequence too and the difference between the consecutive patterns of the sequence is constant.

The next white tiles is calculated by adding multiple of $2$ white tiles to the first pattern and the number of times it is added is based on the position in the sequence.

$
\begin{aligned}
\text{Number of white tiles}  &= 2 + (36 - 1) \times 2 \\\\
                              &= 2 + 35 \times 2 \\\\
                              &= 2 + 70 \\\\
                              &= 72
\end{aligned}
$
solutionDetails.keepInMind:
- Line up digits carefully when adding or subtracting.
- Write the final answer with the correct unit.

children.question: How many tiles will there be in altogether in Shape Number $25?$

solutionDetails.working:
The number of white tiles is calculated by adding $2$ to the previous number of white tiles.

The number of grey tiles is calculated by adding $1$ to the previous number of grey tiles.

This is an arithmetic sequence too and the difference between the consecutive patterns of the sequence is constant.

The next grey tiles is calculated by adding multiple of $1$ grey tiles to the first pattern and the number of times it is added is based on the position in the sequence.

The next white tiles is calculated by adding multiple of $2$ white tiles to the first pattern and the number of times it is added is based on the position in the sequence.


$
\begin{aligned}
\text{Number of white tiles}  &= 2 + (25 - 1) \times 2 \\\\
                              &= 2 + 24 \times 2 \\\\
                              &= 2 + 48 \\\\
                              &= 50
\end{aligned}
$

$
\begin{aligned}
\text{Number of grey tiles}   &= 3 + (25 - 1) \times 1 \\\\
                              &= 3 + 24 \times 1 \\\\
                              &= 3 + 24 \\\\
                              &= 27
\end{aligned}
$

$
\begin{aligned}
\text{Total Number of tiles}  &= 50 + 27 \\\\
                              &= 77
\end{aligned}
$

children.question:
The difference between $\dfrac{1}{3}$ of a certain number and $\dfrac{1}{4}$ of the same number is $3$.

What is the number?

solutionDetails.working:
Let the number $= a$

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
\dfrac {1} {3} \times a - \dfrac {1} {4} \times a                       &= 3 \\\\
\dfrac {a} {3} - \dfrac {a} {4}                                         &= 3 \\\\
\dfrac {a \times 4} {3 \times 4} - \dfrac {a \times 3} {4 \times 3}     &= 3 \\\\
\dfrac {4a} {12} - \dfrac {3a} {12}                                     &= 3 \\\\
\dfrac {4a - 3a} {12}                                                   &= 3 \\\\
4a - 3a                                                                 &= 3 \times 12 \\\\
a                                                                       &= 36
\end{aligned}
$

Number $= 36$
solutionDetails.keepInMind:
- Show each step clearly; don’t do too much in one line.
- Line up digits carefully when adding or subtracting.

children.question:
$383$ and $6226$ are examples of palindromic numbers as they read the
same when the order of their digits is reversed.

Write down the largest five-digit palindromic number that is a multiple of $5$.

solutionDetails.working:
As per the question, the number is a five-digit palindromic number.

Unit place digit of multiple of $5$ can be $= 0$ or $5$. The first digit of five-digit number cannot be $0$ and so the digit at unit place $= 5$.

To get the largest such number, lets make the middle digits as large as possible.

So the number is $5 \ 9 \ 9 \ 9 \ 5$, which is $59995$.

Answer $ = 59995$

children.question:
The order of the digits is reversed in a certain two-digit whole number.

This gives a new whole number which is one less than half of the original number. What is the original number?

solutionDetails.working:
Let the digit at unit place $= a$

Digit at tens place $= b$

Original number $= 10b + a$

Reversed number $= 10a + b$

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
10a + b                     &= \dfrac {1} {2} \times (10b + a) - 1 \\\\
10a + b                     &= \dfrac {10b + a} {2} - 1 \\\\
10a + b + 1                 &= \dfrac {10b + a} {2} \\\\
2 \times (10a + b + 1)      &= 10b + a \\\\
20a + 2b + 2                &= 10b + a \\\\
2                           &= 10b - 2b + a - 20a \\\\
2                           &= 8b - 19a \\\\
8b - 19a                    &= 2 \\\\
8b                          &= 19a + 2 \\\\
b                           &= \dfrac {19a + 2} {8}
\end{aligned}
$

We can easily infer the values by using trial and error. Let's find out a number that satisfies the above equation.

|  $a$  |            $19a + 2$              | Whole Multiple of $8$? |
|:-----:|:---------------------------------:|:----------------:|
| $1$   | $19 \times 1 + 2 = 21$            | No               |
| $2$   | $19 \times 2 + 2 = 40$            | Yes            |
| $3$   | $19 \times 3 + 2 = 59$            | No               |
| $4$   | $19 \times 4 + 2 = 78$            | No               |
| $5$   | $19 \times 5 + 2 = 97$            | No               |
| $6$   | $19 \times 6 + 2 = 116$           | No            |
| $7$   | $19 \times 7 + 2 = 135$           | No               |
| $8$   | $19 \times 8 + 2 = 154$           | No               |
| $9$   | $19 \times 9 + 2 = 173$           | No               |

The digit at unit place $= 2$

$
\begin{aligned}
\text{Digit at tens place}          &= \dfrac {19 \times 2 + 2} {8} \\\\
                                        &= \dfrac {40} {8} \\\\
                                        &= \dfrac {5 \times 8} {8} \\\\
                                        &= \dfrac {5 \times \cancel 8} {\cancel 8} \\\\
                                        &= 5
\end{aligned}
$

Original number $= 52$

Every digit of a certain positive whole number is either a $3$ or $4$, with each occurring at least one.

The number divides exactly by both $3$ and $4$.

What is the smallest number it could be?

solutionDetails.working:
Using trial and error,

Smallest required number $= 3444$

Let's verify.

$
\begin{aligned}
&= \dfrac {3444} {3 \times 4} \\\\
&= \dfrac {3 \times 4 \times 287} {3 \times 4} \\\\
&= \dfrac {\cancel 3 \times \cancel 4 \times 287} {\cancel 3 \times \cancel 4} \\\\
&= 287
\end{aligned}
$

questions.question:
Hareni has twice as many sweets as Dora.
After eating $18$ sweets each, she has five times as many as Dora. How many sweets did Hareni start with?

solutionDetails.working:
Let at the start number of sweets Dora has $= a$

Number of sweets Hareni has $= 2a$

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
5 \times (a - 18)       &= 2a - 18 \\\\
5a - 5 \times 18        &= 2a - 18 \\\\
5a - 90                 &= 2a - 18 \\\\
5a - 2a                 &= 90 - 18 \\\\
3a                      &= 72 \\\\
a                       &= \dfrac {72} {3} \\\\
a                       &= \dfrac {3 \times 24} {3} \\\\
a                       &= \dfrac {\cancel 3 \times 24} {\cancel 3} \\\\
a                       &= 24
\end{aligned}
$

$
\begin{aligned}
\text{Sweets Hareni has initially}       &= 24 \times 2 \\\\
                                         &= 48
\end{aligned}
$

Three cereal bars, two apples and one tube of mints cost $\pounds 3.14$.

Two cereal bars, three apples and four tube of mints cost $\pounds 4.21$.

What is the total cost of buying one cereal bar, one apple and one tube of mints?

solutionDetails.working:
Let the price of one cereal bar $= c$

Price of one apple $= a$

Price of one tube of mint $= m$

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
3c + 2a + m             &= 3.14 \\\\
2c + 3a + 4m            &= 4.21
\end{aligned}
$

Let's add both the equations.

$
\begin{aligned}
3c + 2a + m + 2c + 3a + 4m          &= 3.14 + 4.21 \\\\
5c + 5a + 5m                        &= 7.35 \\\\
5 \times (c + a + m)                       &= 7.35 \\\\
c + a + m                           &= \dfrac {7.35} {5} \\\\
c + a + m                           &= \pounds 1.47
\end{aligned}
$

Total cost $= \pounds 1.47$
solutionDetails.keepInMind:
- When dividing by a fraction, multiply by the reciprocal.
- Use the correct order of operations (BIDMAS).

children.question:
The tables in the Dining Hall can each seat $8$ pupils.

How many tables are needed to seat $180$ pupils?

solutionDetails.working:
$
\begin{aligned}
\text{Total tables needed}                    &= \dfrac {\text{Total pupils}} {\text{Pupil per table}} \\\\
                                              &= \dfrac {180} {8} \\\\
                                              &= 22 \ \text{remainder } 4 \\\\
                                              &\approx 23
\end{aligned}
$

We need $1$ more table for the remaining $4$ pupils.

Total tables = $22 + 1 = 23$

children.question:
Jake paid a $\pounds 50$ deposit for a bike, then monthly
payments of $\pounds 25$ each. The bike cost $\pounds 275$.

How many monthly payments did Jake have to make to buy it?

solutionDetails.alternativeWorking:
**Alternative working 1**

Let the number of monthly payments $= n$

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
50 + 25n                                      &= 275 \\\\
25n                                           &= 275 - 50 \\\\
25n                                           &= 225 \\\\
n                                             &= \dfrac {225} {25} \\\\
n                                             &= \dfrac {9 \times 25} {25} \\\\
n                                             &= \dfrac {9 \times \cancel{25}} {\cancel{25}} \\\\
n                                             &= 9
\end{aligned}
$

Number of monthly payments $= 9$

Perimeter of square = 4 × side

children.question:
There are $500$ pupils at Lily's school.

There are $30$ more girls than boys.

How many girls are there?

solutionDetails.working:
Let the number of girls $= g$

Number of boys $= g - 30$

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
g + (g - 30)                                         &= 500 \\\\
2g                                                   &= 500 + 30 \\\\
2g                                                   &= 530 \\\\
g                                                    &= \dfrac {530} {2} \\\\
g                                                    &= \dfrac {2 \times 265} {2} \\\\
g                                                    &= \dfrac {\cancel{2} \times 265} {\cancel{2}} \\\\
g                                                    &= 265
\end{aligned}
$

Number of girls $= 265$
solutionDetails.keepInMind: - Line up digits carefully when adding or subtracting.

children.question:
The sum of five consecutive whole numbers is $100$.

What is the smallest of these five numbers?

solutionDetails.working:
Let the five consecutive whole numbers $= a - 2, a - 1, a , a + 1, a + 2$

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
(a - 2) + (a - 1) + a + (a + 1) + (a + 2)   &= 100 \\\\
5a                                  &= 100 \\\\
a                                   &= \dfrac {100} {5} \\\\
a                                   &= \dfrac {20 \times 5} {5} \\\\
a                                   &= \dfrac {20 \times \cancel 5} {\cancel 5} \\\\
a                                   &= 20
\end{aligned}
$

$
\begin{aligned}
\text{Smallest whole number}        &= a - 2 \\\\
                                    &= 20 - 2 \\\\
                                    &= 18
\end{aligned}
$

children.question:
The sum of two numbers is $22$ and their difference is $4$.

What are the two numbers?

solutionDetails.working:
Let the two numbers are $= a, b$

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
a + b       &= 22 \\\\
a - b       &= 4
\end{aligned}
$

Let's add both the equations.

$
\begin{aligned}
a + b + a - b           &= 22 + 4 \\\\
2a                      &= 26 \\\\
a                       &= \dfrac {2 \times 13} {2} \\\\
a                       &= \dfrac {\cancel 2 \times 13} {\cancel 2} \\\\
a                       &= 13
\end{aligned}
$

Let's substitute the value of $a$ in one of the initial equations to find $b$.

$
\begin{aligned}
a + b                   &= 22 \\\\
b                       &= 22 - a \\\\
b                       &= 22 - 13 \\\\
b                       &= 9
\end{aligned}
$

Numbers $= 13, 9$

questions.question:
At Ali's shop, a multipack of $8$ toilet rolls costs $\pounds 2.40$.

At Mya's shop, the cost per toilet roll is twice as much.

How much is a pack of $3$ toilet rolls at Mya's shop?

solutionDetails.working:
$
\begin{aligned}
\text{Cost at Ali's shop}                   &= \dfrac {2.40} {8} \\\\
                                            &= \pounds 0.30 \\\\
\text{Cost at Mya's shop}                   &= 0.30 \times 2 \\\\
                                            &= \pounds 0.60 \\\\
\text{Cost of 3 rolls at Mya's shop}        &= 0.60 \times 3 \\\\
                                            &= \pounds 1.80
\end{aligned}
$
solutionDetails.keepInMind:
- Show each step clearly; don’t do too much in one line.
- Use the correct order of operations (BIDMAS).

Each number in a sequence is calculated by multiplying the previous number by $100$ then adding $1$.

children.question: If the first number in the sequence is $0$, what is the fourth number?

solutionDetails.keepInMind: - Line up digits carefully when adding or subtracting.

children.question: If the second number in the sequence is $51$, what is the first number?

solutionDetails.working:
Let the first number $= a$

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
a \times 100 + 1        &= 51 \\\\
100a                    &= 51 - 1 \\\\
a                       &= \dfrac {50} {100} \\\\
a                       &= \dfrac {50} {2 \times 50} \\\\
a                       &= \dfrac {\cancel {50}} {2 \times \cancel {50}} \\\\
a                       &= \dfrac {1} {2}
\end{aligned}
$

First number $= \dfrac {1} {2}$

questions.question:
A sequence of numbers is formed by always adding the same number
to get the next number in the sequence.

The $10 ^ \text{th}$ number in the sequence is $23$ and the $15 ^\text{th}$ number is $38$.

What is the $12 ^ \text{th}$ number?

solutionDetails.working:
Let the difference $= d$

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
23 + 5d                         &= 38 \\\\
5d                              &= 38 - 23 \\\\
5d                              &= 15 \\\\
d                               &= \dfrac{15}{5} \\\\
d                               &= \dfrac{5 \times 3}{5} \\\\
d                               &= \dfrac{\cancel{5} \times 3}{\cancel{5}} \\\\
d                               &= 3 \\\\
12 ^ {\text{th}} \text{ number} &= 23 + 2 \times 3 \\\\
                                &= 23 + 6 \\\\
                                &= 29
\end{aligned}
$

children.question: What is the area of one tile?

solutionDetails.working:
As per the diagram,

$
\begin{aligned}
\text {Area of one tile}            &= \dfrac {\text {Area of the cross}} {\text {Number of tiles}} \\\\
                                    &= \dfrac {245} {5} \\\\
                                    &= \dfrac {49 \times 5} {5} \\\\
                                    &= \dfrac {49 \times \cancel {5}} {\cancel {5}} \\\\
                                    &= 49 \ \text{cm}^2
\end{aligned}
$

children.question: What is the length of one side of a tile?

solutionDetails.working:
Let the length of one side of tile $= a$

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
a \times a          &= 49 \\\\
a^2                 &= 49 \\\\
a                   &= \sqrt {49} \\\\
a                   &= 7 \ \text{cm}
\end{aligned}
$

Length of one side of tile $= 7 \ \text{cm}$.

How many litres of paint would it take to cover the surface of the shape on the right?

solutionDetails.working:
$
\begin{aligned}
\text {Number of faces painted}           &= 9 \times 6  \\\\
                                          &= 54 \\\\
\text {Litres required to paint one face} &= \dfrac {9} {54} \\\\
                                          &= \dfrac {9} {9 \times 6} \\\\
                                          &= \dfrac {\cancel 9} {\cancel 9 \times 6} \\\\
                                          &= \dfrac {1} {6} \\\\
\end{aligned}
$

$
\begin{aligned}
\text {Number of faces to be painted}     &= 9 \times 3 + 5 \times 3 + 4 \times 3  \\\\
                                          &= 54 \\\\
\text {Litres required to paint 54 face}  &= \dfrac {1} {6} \times 54 \\\\
                                          &= \dfrac {1} {6} \times 9 \times 6\\\\
                                          &= \dfrac {1} {\cancel 6} \times 9 \times \cancel 6\\\\
                                          &= 9 \ \text{litres} \\\\
\end{aligned}
$

questions.question:
Twelve people (and no more) can sit evenly spaced around a square table.

Deesha puts eight of these square tables together in a row to make one very long rectangular table.

What is the maximum number of people that can sit evenly spaced around this long table?

solutionDetails.working:
The long rectangle has $2$ long sides and $2$ short sides.

Each short side is same as $1$ side of a square table.
Each square table contributes one segment of the long side. Each long side is same as side of $8$ square tables.

$
\begin{aligned}
\text{Number of people on each side of square table}    &= \dfrac {12} {4} \\\\
                                                        &= \dfrac {3 \times \cancel 4} {\cancel 4} \\\\
                                                        &= 3 \\\\
\text{Number of people on long table}          & = 2 \times \text{(people on short sides)} + 2 \times \text{(people on long sides)} \\\\
&= 2 \times 3 + 2 \times 8 \times 3  \\\\
                                                        &= 6 + 48 \\\\
                                                        &= 54
\end{aligned}
$
solutionDetails.keepInMind:
- Line up digits carefully when adding or subtracting.
- When dividing by a fraction, multiply by the reciprocal.

questions.question: The school site covers an area of $8000 \ \text{m}^2$.

children.question: Buildings take up $\dfrac{3}{5}$ of the area. How much area is this?

solutionDetails.working:
As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
\text {Area of Building}            &= \dfrac {3} {5} \times \text {Area of site} \\\\
                                    &= \dfrac {3} {5} \times 8000 \\\\
                                    &= \dfrac {3 \times 8000} {5} \\\\
                                    &= \dfrac {3 \times 5 \times 1600} {5} \\\\
                                    &= \dfrac {3 \times \cancel {5} \times 1600} {\cancel {5}} \\\\
                                    &= 3 \times 1600 \\\\
                                    &= 4800 \ \text{cm}^2
\end{aligned}
$
solutionDetails.formulasUsed:
Area of square = side²
1 m = 100 cm

children.question: The playground takes up $\dfrac{1}{4}$ of what is left. How much area is this?

solutionDetails.working:
As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
\text {Area of playground}          &= \dfrac {1} {4} \times \text {Area of site} \\\\
                                    &= \dfrac {1} {4} \times 8000 \\\\
                                    &= \dfrac {1 \times 8000} {4} \\\\
                                    &= \dfrac {1 \times 4 \times 2000} {4} \\\\
                                    &= \dfrac {1 \times \cancel {4} \times 2000} {\cancel {4}} \\\\
                                    &= 1 \times 2000 \\\\
                                    &= 2000 \ \text{cm}^2
\end{aligned}
$
solutionDetails.formulasUsed:
Percentage = (part ÷ whole) × 100%
Perimeter of square = 4 × side

children.question: The rest of the site is footpaths and grass. How much area is this?

solutionDetails.working:
As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
\text {Area of footpath and grass}  &= \text {Area of site} - \text {Area of Building} - \text {Area of playground} \\\\
                                    &= 8000 - 4800 - 2000 \\\\
                                    &= 1200 \ \text{cm}^2
\end{aligned}
$

children.question:
The area of the grass is seven times the area of the footpaths.

What area is covered in grass?

solutionDetails.working:
Let the area of the footpath $= a$

Area of the grass $= 7a$

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
\text {Area of grass} + \text {Area of footpath}    &= 1200 \\\\
7a + a                                              &= 1200 \\\\
8a                                                  &= 1200 \\\\
a                                                   &= \dfrac {1200} {8} \\\\
a                                                   &= \dfrac {8 \times 150} {8} \\\\
a                                                   &= \dfrac {\cancel {8} \times 150} {\cancel {8}} \\\\
a                                                   &= 150 \ \text{cm}^2
\end{aligned}
$

Let's find the area of the grass.

$
\begin{aligned}
\text {Area of the grass}   &= 7 \times a \\\\
                            &= 7 \times 150 \\\\
                            &= 1050 \ \text{cm}^2
\end{aligned}
$
solutionDetails.keepInMind: - Write the final answer with the correct unit.
