children.question: She worked out that the median number of passengers was $30$. Show what working she used to get this answer.

solutionDetails.working:
Let's arrange the numbers in ascending order.

$
\begin{aligned}
\text{Numbers}\            &= 5, \quad 24, \quad 37, \quad 45, \quad 36, \quad 39, \quad 22, \quad 16 \\\\
\text{Ordered numbers}\    &= 5, \quad 16, \quad 22, \quad \rtq_katex_color_info{24}, \quad \rtq_katex_color_info{36}, \quad 37, \quad 39, \quad 45 \\\\
\text{Median}\             &= \dfrac {24 + 36} {2} \\\\
                           &= \dfrac {60} {2} \\\\
                           &= \dfrac {2 \times 30} {2} \\\\
                           &= \dfrac {\cancel 2 \times 30} {\cancel 2} \\\\
                           &= 30
\end{aligned}
$

children.question: In shape $6$, how many triangles will there be?

solutionDetails.working:
The number of triangles is calculated by adding $2$ to the previous number of triangles.

This is an arithmetic sequence too and the difference between the consecutive patterns of the sequence is constant.

The next pattern is made by adding multiple of $2$ triangles to the first pattern and the number of times it is added is based on the position in the sequence.

$
\begin{aligned}
\text{Number of triangles}    &= 1 + (6 - 1) \times 2 \\\\
                              &= 1 + 5 \times 2 \\\\
                              &= 1 + 10 \\\\
                              &= 11
\end{aligned}
$

children.question: In shape $6$, how many matches will there be?

solutionDetails.working:
The number of matches is calculated by adding $4$ to the previous number of matches.

This is an arithmetic sequence too and the difference between the consecutive patterns of the sequence is constant.

The next pattern is made by adding multiple of $4$ matches to the first pattern and the number of times it is added is based on the position in the sequence.

$
\begin{aligned}
\text{Number of matches}      &= 3 + (6 - 1) \times 4 \\\\
                              &= 3 + 5 \times 4 \\\\
                              &= 3 + 20 \\\\
                              &= 23
\end{aligned}
$
solutionDetails.keepInMind: - Use the correct order of operations (BIDMAS).

children.question:
In shape $100$, how many triangles will there be?

Explain how you worked this out.

solutionDetails.working:
The number of triangles is calculated by adding $2$ to the previous number of triangles.

This is an arithmetic sequence too and the difference between the consecutive patterns of the sequence is constant.

The next pattern is made by adding multiple of $2$ triangles to the first pattern and the number of times it is added is based on the position in the sequence.

$
\begin{aligned}
\text{Number of triangles}    &= 1 + (100 - 1) \times 2 \\\\
                              &= 1 + 99 \times 2 \\\\
                              &= 1 + 198 \\\\
                              &= 199
\end{aligned}
$

children.question:
In shape $100$, how many matches will there be?

Explain how you worked this out.

solutionDetails.working:
The number of matches is calculated by adding $4$ to the previous number of matches.

This is an arithmetic sequence too and the difference between the consecutive patterns of the sequence is constant.

The next pattern is made by adding multiple of $4$ matches to the first pattern and the number of times it is added is based on the position in the sequence.

$
\begin{aligned}
\text{Number of matches}      &= 3 + (100 - 1) \times 4 \\\\
                              &= 3 + 99 \times 4 \\\\
                              &= 3 + 396 \\\\
                              &= 399
\end{aligned}
$

children.question: Anah makes a shape with $29$ triangles. How many matches did she use?

solutionDetails.working:
The number of triangles is calculated by adding $2$ to the previous number of triangles.

The number of matches is calculated by adding $4$ to the previous number of matches.

This is an arithmetic sequence too and the difference between the consecutive patterns of the sequence is constant.

The next pattern is made by adding multiple of $4$ matches and adding multiple of $2$ triangles to the first pattern and the number of times it is added is based on the position in the sequence.

Let the term number $= a$

$
\begin{aligned}
1 + (a - 1) \times 2    &=  29 \\\\
1 + 2a - 2              &=  29 \\\\
2a - 1                  &=  29 \\\\
2a                      &=  29 + 1 \\\\
2a                      &=  30 \\\\
a                       &=  \dfrac{30}{2} \\\\
a                       &=  \dfrac{15 \times 2}{2} \\\\
a                       &=  \dfrac{15 \times \cancel{2}}{\cancel{2}} \\\\
a                       &=  15
\end{aligned}
$

$
\begin{aligned}
\text{Number of matches}    &= 3 + (15 - 1) \times 4 \\\\
                            &= 3 + 14 \times 4 \\\\
                            &= 3 + 98 \\\\
                            &= 101 \\\\
\end{aligned}
$

The number of triangles is calculated by adding $2$ to the previous number of triangles.

The number of matches is calculated by adding $4$ to the previous number of matches.

| shape               | $1$ | $2$ | $3$  | $4$  |
|---------------------|-----|-----|------|------|
| Number of triangles | $1$ | $3$ | $5$  | $7$  |
| Number of matches   | $3$ | $7$ | $11$ | $15$ |

questions.question:
I roll a bouncy ball down the stairs. It bounces once after $2$ steps, then again after double the number of steps.
It carries on falling, bouncing after triple the number of steps it had bounced originally.
At this point how many steps lower is the ball than where it started?

solutionDetails.working:
$
\begin{aligned}
\text{Number of steps before 1st bounce}        &= 2 \\\\
\text{Number of steps before 2nd bounce}        &= 2 \times 2 \\\\
                                                &= 4 \\\\
\text{Number of steps before 3rd bounce}        &= 2 \times 3 \\\\
                                                &= 6
\end{aligned}
$

$
\begin{aligned}
\text{Total number of steps}        &= 2 + 4 + 6 \\\\
                                    &= 12
\end{aligned}
$

Number of steps the ball lowered after it started rolling $= 12$
solutionDetails.keepInMind: - Line up digits carefully when adding or subtracting.

solutionDetails.working:
As per the diagram,

$
\begin{aligned}
x + 104     &= 180   \\\\
x           &= 180  - 104  \\\\
x           &= 76 \degree
\end{aligned}
$

Let's use the value of $x$ to find $y$.

$
\begin{aligned}
x  + y + y              &= 180 \\\\
76  + 2y                &= 180 \\\\
2y                      &= 180  - 76 \\\\
2y                      &= 104  \\\\
y                       &= \dfrac {104 } {2}   \\\\
y                       &= \dfrac {52 \times 2} {2}   \\\\
y                       &= \dfrac {52 \times \cancel {2}} {\cancel {2}} \\\\
y                       &= 52 \degree
\end{aligned}
$

children.question: My rabbit is called $\text{ANNA}$, what is the sum of the letters in her name?
My gerbil's name is $\blacklozenge \text{AE}$. If the sum of the letter in her name is $-19$, what is the missing letter?

solutionDetails.working:
Let the value of the missing letter be $=a$

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
a - 1 - 5                           &= - 19 \\\\
a - 6                               &= - 19 \\\\
a                                   &= - 19 + 6 \\\\
a                                   &= - 13 \\\\
a                                   &= \text{M}
\end{aligned}
$

Missing letter $= \text{M}$

children.question:
Individual triangles are to be painted BLUE or RED, so that no adjoining triangles have the same colour.
In how many ways can this be done?

solutionDetails.working:
If we use blue in the centre triangle, the only possible option for other adjoining triangles is red.

If we use red in the centre triangle, the only possible option for other adjoining triangles is blue.

Total Count $= 1 + 1 = 2$
solutionDetails.alternativeWorking:
**Alternative working 1**

Using permutation,

Number of ways of painting the centre triangle (red or blue) $= 2$

Number of ways of painting the remaining adjoining triangles $= 1$

Total arrangements $= 2 \times 1 = 2$
solutionDetails.keepInMind: - Check units and convert if needed.

questions.question:
Mr Rich decided to share his wealth among his children.

Richie as the oldest got $\dfrac{1}{3}$,
Thrifty the second oldest got a $\dfrac{1}{3}$ of what was left,
Bounty got $\dfrac{1}{2}$ of what was left once Richie and Thrifty got their share.
The dog, Archie, got the rest.

If Mr Rich shared $\pounds 9$ million pounds, how much did Archie get?

solutionDetails.working:
As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
\text{Archie's share of wealth}     &= \pounds \dfrac {1} {2} \times \left( \dfrac {2} {3} \times \left( \dfrac {2} {3} \times 9000000 \right) \right) \\\\
                                    &= \dfrac {1} {2} \times \dfrac {2} {3} \times \dfrac {2} {3} \times 9000000 \\\\
                                    &= \dfrac {1 \times 2 \times 2 \times 9000000} {2 \times 3 \times 3} \\\\
                                    &= \dfrac {2 \times 2 \times 3 \times 3 \times 1000000} {2 \times 3 \times 3} \\\\
                                    &= \dfrac {2 \times \cancel 2 \times \cancel 3 \times \cancel 3 \times 1000000} {\cancel 2 \times \cancel 3 \times \cancel 3} \\\\
                                    &= 2 \times 1000000 \\\\
                                    &= \pounds 2000000
\end{aligned}
$

Share of Archie in Mr Rich wealth $= \pounds 2 \ \text{million}$.

- Use the correct order of operations (BIDMAS).
- Check units and convert if needed.

questions.question:
The symbol $\spadesuit$ placed between two numbers means “multiply together then add three”.

For example: $3 \ \spadesuit \ 5 = 3 \times 5 + 3 = 15 + 3 = 18$

children.question: What is $5 \ \spadesuit \ 10?$

solutionDetails.keepInMind:
- Show each step clearly; don’t do too much in one line.
- Write the final answer with the correct unit.

children.question: If $x  \ \spadesuit \  4 = 23$, what number is $x$?

solutionDetails.working:
As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
x  \ \spadesuit \  4        &= 23 \\\\
x \times 4 + 3              &= 23 \\\\
4x                  &= 23 - 3 \\\\
x                           &= \dfrac {20} {4} \\\\
x                           &= \dfrac {4 \times 5} {4} \\\\
x                           &= \dfrac {\cancel 4 \times 5} {\cancel 4} \\\\
x                           &= 5
\end{aligned}
$

children.question: If $y  \ \spadesuit \  y = 39$, what could $y$ be?

solutionDetails.working:
As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
y  \ \spadesuit \  y        &= 39 \\\\
y \times y + 3              &= 39 \\\\
y \times y                  &= 39 - 3 \\\\
y ^ 2                       &= 36 \\\\
y                           &= \sqrt {36} \\\\
y                           &= 6, -6
\end{aligned}
$
solutionDetails.formulasUsed:
Perimeter of square = 4 × side
Percentage = (part ÷ whole) × 100%

children.question:
Another new mathematical symbol has also been invented.

$\bigstar$ means “multiply together, unless the answer would be odd in which case add together instead”.

So $3  \ \bigstar \  4 = 12$ (because $3 \times 4$ is even)

While $5   \ \bigstar \   7 = 12$ (because $5 \times 7$ would be odd, so we add $5$ and $7$ instead!)

What is $2   \ \bigstar \   8?$

solutionDetails.working:
$2 \times 8 = 16$ is even and so we multiply:

$
\begin{aligned}
&= 2 \ \bigstar \ 8 \\\\
&= 2 \times 8 \\\\
&= 16
\end{aligned}
$
solutionDetails.keepInMind: - When dividing by a fraction, multiply by the reciprocal.

children.question: What is $11   \ \bigstar \   7?$

solutionDetails.working:
$11 \times 7 = 77$ is odd and so we add:

$
\begin{aligned}
&= 11 \ \bigstar \ 7 \\\\
&= 11 + 7 \\\\
&= 18
\end{aligned}
$

children.question: If $x   \ \bigstar \   2 = 30$, what is the number $x$?

solutionDetails.working:
$2$ is even, so $x \times 2$ is always even. so we multiply:

As per the question,

$
\begin{aligned}
x \ \bigstar \ 2        &= 30 \\\\
x \times 2              &= 30 \\\\
x                       &= \dfrac {30} {2} \\\\
x                       &= \dfrac {2 \times 15} {2} \\\\
x                       &= \dfrac {\cancel 2 \times 15} {\cancel 2} \\\\
x                       &= 15
\end{aligned}
$
solutionDetails.keepInMind: - When dividing by a fraction, multiply by the reciprocal.
solutionDetails.formulasUsed: Area of triangle = ½ × base × height

children.question: If $y   \ \bigstar \   3 = 24$, there are two possible values of $y$. What are they?

solutionDetails.working:
$3$ is odd, so $y \times 3$ is odd when $y$ is odd, and even when $y$ is even.


Case $1$ ($y$ is even):

$
\begin{aligned}
y \ \bigstar \ 3        &= 24 \\\\
y \times 3              &= 24 \\\\
y                       &= \dfrac {24} {3} \\\\
y                       &= \dfrac {3 \times 8} {3} \\\\
y                       &= \dfrac {\cancel 3 \times 8} {\cancel 3} \\\\
y                       &= 8
\end{aligned}
$

Case $2$ ($y$ is odd):

$
\begin{aligned}
y \ \bigstar \ 3        &= 24 \\\\
y + 3                   &= 24 \\\\
y                       &= 24 - 3 \\\\
y                       &= 21
\end{aligned}
$

$y = 8$, $21$
solutionDetails.keepInMind: - When dividing by a fraction, multiply by the reciprocal.
solutionDetails.formulasUsed: Area of triangle = ½ × base × height
